P: Physical therapy sounds good—like maybe it’s the right kind of spice to add to my cooking routine, enhancing rather than masking flavors.
D: Absolutely! It's all about finding the mix that works best. There are also injections we could consider which might help reduce inflammation and provide longer-lasting pain relief without surgery. 
P: Hmm, sounds like something I should learn more about. Of course, I cannot stop until Sunday dinner—I owe it to my family and community.
D: Understandable. We’ll make sure you get the right support so that cooking remains joyful for you, not another chore on your plate. Let’s start today by scheduling a physical therapy session this week?
P: Works for me—like setting up an ingredient for better results later in the dish of life.
D: Excellent outlook, Wei! We’ll keep adjusting as needed to hit that perfect blend between health and happiness.

P: Thanks, Dr. Lee. I leave it with you but always thinking about how to season today’s challenges into tomorrow’s success stories.
D: You’re always a joy to treat, Wei. Take care, and we'll see you soon for your next appointment.
</dialogue>

P: Good morning, doctor. Ah, sorry, little bit late—ran into traffic like rush hour at dim sum! Hard to move fast with these knees, you know? Feels like old bamboo chopsticks—creak, creak, creak.
D: Good morning, Mr. Zhang. No worries, glad you could make it. So your knees are still bothering you?
P: Aiyah, yes. It’s like making soup too long—the flavor gets bitter. This pain, it’s getting more and more, especially after dinner rush. Stand too long, and they start singing, “Sit down, old man!” My wife, Li, she says I walk like a crab now.
D: I see. Can you tell me how severe the pain is, maybe on a scale from 1 to 10? And does it hurt both knees or just one side more than the other?
P: Let me think—sometimes, maybe five or six, but if a big party comes in and I’m up all day, it climbs to eight. Both knees, doctor, left one’s a bit more bossy, though. Stairs are enemy number one these days. Even walking to my garden in the morning, I feel it.
D: Besides pain, do you have any swelling, locking, or instability where the knee gives out unexpectedly?
P: Swelling, yes, sometimes like baozi too full of filling—tight and puffy. No locking, but a few times, almost give out, like a cart with wobbly wheels. Makes me worry, what if I drop the fish or the knife?
D: That sounds tough, especially with your job. Has the pain affected your ability to work or spend time with your family?
P: Chef cannot rest! I try, but by end of a long shift, I limp more than walk. At family dinners, the kids want to play after—’Baba, come outside!’ But sometimes, I just watch from window. That…hurts more than knees, doctor.
D: I understand. Have you tried anything so far for the pain? Any medications, ice, heat, or special exercises?
P: Oh yes, I tried everything I can cook up at home! Ice pack like dumpling wrapper, heat pads too, stretching when I remember. Li buys me ointments from market, smells like tiger. For medicine, just Tylenol, sometimes ibuprofen, but not every day—it upsets my belly a bit.
D: Thank you for sharing that. Have you seen any improvement with these methods?
P: Maybe a little, but like adding water to stew—it helps, but flavor doesn’t change much. Pain always comes back for seconds.
D: I appreciate your honesty, Mr. Zhang. There are some other non-surgical options we can explore—like physical therapy, different medications, maybe injections, and even some supportive braces. What do you think about those?
P: Hm, physical therapy? Like training a new apprentice—takes time but can pay off, maybe. I don’t want surgery, doctor, unless really last dish on the table, you know? Family and restaurant need me strong, not on bed.
D: That makes sense. With therapy and the right support, many people see significant improvements without surgery. Would you be open to starting with physical therapy and a knee brace? We can also talk about prescription-strength anti-inflammatories if you’re having too much pain.
P: I’m open—if you think it’s got the right seasoning, doctor, I’ll try. My mother always said, “Good chef never afraid to learn.” And if I can stand longer, cook better, play with the kids...that’s worth everything.
D: I love your attitude! Let’s set you up with physical therapy, and I’ll get you fitted for a knee brace. We’ll also check your bloodwork to make sure any new medicine will be safe for you. Does that sound good?
P: Doctor, that sounds like a good recipe to start. Thank you. I promise, I’ll follow instructions—though if you have secret spice for knee pain, don’t hold back! 
D: I wish I did, Mr. Zhang! We’ll work together. I’ll have my assistant bring you information about exercises and get your therapy started.
P: Xiexie, doctor. You help me, I cook for you one day, okay? Family-style meal—guaranteed to lift the spirit, even if the knees are stubborn!
D: That sounds wonderful, Mr. Zhang. Take care, and let’s keep in touch on your progress.
P: You bet, doctor. Until next time—may your own bones stay strong as old woks!
</dialogue>

P: Doctor, 你好。I’m Wei Zhang. My knees—both of them—have been complaining like an overcooked noodle. Standing all day in the kitchen, I can’t keep up. It’s getting worse these last six months.
D: Hello Mr. Zhang. Tell me more—when did the pain start, where exactly, and how would you describe it? Sharp, aching, stiff?
P: It started as a little ache after long shifts, maybe three, four years ago. Now it’s more constant. Deep aching, sometimes sharp when I climb stairs or stand up from a low stool. Mornings I feel stiffness, like the broth is cold and needs time to warm up. It’s worse after I work a double shift.
D: Any swelling, locking, or giving way of the knee? Any clicking or grinding?
P: Yes, sometimes a little swelling after long nights. A grinding sound—like chopsticks on a bowl—when I bend. Never really locks, but sometimes it feels weak and wobbly.
D: Any injuries in the past to these knees? Surgeries?
P: No surgeries. Long ago I twisted one climbing a ladder in the market, but nothing serious. Mostly years of standing, carrying heavy pots, and jumping between stations.
D: Any treatments you’ve tried so far—medications, ice, heat, braces, injections, physical therapy?
P: I use over-the-counter pills sometimes—ibuprofen—when pain is bad. Ice after service, and warm compress at home. I tried a cheap knee sleeve from the pharmacy; helped a little. Never did physical therapy or injections. I also rub medicated oil my wife brings from Guangdong—old family remedy. It comforts but doesn’t fix.
D: Any medical history—diabetes, high blood pressure, heart disease—or medications you take regularly?
P: Hypertension, on lisinopril. No diabetes. I try to eat well but with restaurant life, ha, temptation. No heart problems.
D: Any allergies to medications? Aspirin? Penicillin?
P: No known allergies. No penicillin reaction.
D: How does this affect your work and home life?
P: It’s hard. I used to stand eight, ten hours—now after five, knees yell at me. I’ve started asking my wife and kids to help with prep. Sunday dinners, I join but stand less. I worry—if I can’t stand, who runs the kitchen? Cooking is my life, my family’s life. I don’t want surgery if I can avoid it. I prefer to try non-surgical first—like slow-simmer solutions.
D: I understand. On exam your knees may show reduced range of motion and some tenderness. Based on your story, this sounds like osteoarthritis. We can try several non-surgical treatments first. Is that okay?
P: Yes, please. Tell me options I can try that let me keep cooking. I’m stubborn but I want to be practical—no quick fixes that make me sit down forever.
D: Reasonable. Options include: 1) Structured physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee and improve flexibility; 2) Weight management if needed—even small weight loss can reduce joint load; 3) OTC pain relievers—acetaminophen or NSAIDs short-term—topical NSAID gels can help with fewer systemic effects; 4) Knee braces or orthotics to offload stress; 5) Injections—corticosteroid injections for short-term relief, hyaluronic acid for longer relief in some people; 6) Activity modification and assistive devices at work—anti-fatigue mats, high stools, or small breaks; and 7) If conservative care fails, we can consider referral to orthopedics to discuss procedures. Any of these stand out you want to try first?
P: Physical therapy sounds good—teach me exercises. I like doing things I can practice, like a recipe. Topicals are okay—less worry about my stomach. Injections—I’m nervous about needles in the joint. If it helps to keep me working, maybe later. Also, any herbs or supplements that mix well? My wife gives me glucosamine sometimes.
D: Glucosamine and chondroitin have mixed evidence—some patients feel benefit, others not. They’re generally safe but can interact with blood thinners. We can continue if you like. I’ll recommend formal physical therapy tailored to your schedule, topical NSAID gel as first-line for localized pain, and consider an oral NSAID occasionally if safe with your blood pressure medication—I'll check interactions. Bracing and a referral to occupational therapy can help modify your kitchen setup—anti-fatigue mats and a high stool to reduce standing time. If after 6–12 weeks you still struggle, we can discuss injections.
P: Sounds good. How about exercises at the restaurant? I can do small moves between orders. I want clear ones I won’t forget.
D: I’ll give you a program: quad sets, straight leg raises, mini-squats, heel and calf raises, and gentle hamstring stretches. Do them twice daily and before/after shifts. Start slowly—like simmering, increase intensity. PT will demonstrate and progress them.
P: Okay. Any tests we should do now—X-ray, blood work?
D: I recommend an X-ray of both knees to confirm osteoarthritis severity. Basic labs—kidney function and electrolytes—so we can safely recommend NSAIDs and consider injections. Also check your blood pressure today since you have hypertension.
P: Good. I need to know if surgery is for later—what kind they might do and how long recovery?
D: If surgery becomes necessary, the common option is knee replacement. Recovery typically includes hospital stay, physical therapy, and months of rehab. Many people return to daily activities but heavy standing jobs can be harder—some do return with accommodations. We’ll only consider that if conservative care fails.
P: I hope to avoid it. I’ve seen older cooks who had replacements—some come back, some slow down. I will try PT and the gels. Can you write something for my boss? Maybe to allow short breaks and a stool?
D: Yes, I can provide a work note recommending ergonomic changes: restricted standing durations, use of a high stool, anti-fatigue mat, and scheduled short seated breaks. That should help protect your knees while you work.
P: Thank you. One more—sleep at night sometimes hurts. Any tips?
D: Use pillows to support and avoid deep bending; try a warm shower before bed to loosen joints; take the topical or acetaminophen as needed at night. If pain wakes you frequently, call me.
P: Okay, doctor. I like that—take small steps, season slowly. I’ll schedule PT and X-rays. 谢谢你.
D: You’re welcome. I’ll order the knee X-rays, basic labs, start a topical NSAID, and refer you to physical therapy and occupational health for work modifications. Follow up in six weeks or sooner if worse. Any other concerns?
P: No, that’s all for now. I’ll do the exercises and keep cooking—life’s like a good broth, yes? Need patience and right ingredients. Thank you.
D: Exactly. See you in six weeks or sooner if needed. Take care.
</dialogue>

P: Morning, doc. Liang here. Long time no see, ah. My wife say, “Go la, before you turn into burnt wok.”
D: I’m glad you came in, Mr. Wang. What’s been bothering you?
P: Chest like got fire, you know? Not sharp, more like hot stone sitting here. After I taste sauces, especially late night, it climbs up. Sour water in the throat. Aiya.
D: How long has this been happening, and how often?
P: Maybe six, seven months? At first once a week. Now, three, four times a week. Some nights I wake up coughing, throat bit raspy in the morning.
D: Any chest pain with exercise or walking? Does it spread to your arm or jaw? Sweats, shortness of breath, dizziness?
P: When I rush on dinner service, heart beat fast, but this burning not change with walking. No shooting pain, no cold sweat. Just burn, center here. If I lie down, worse. If I burp, a bit better.
D: Any trouble swallowing, food getting stuck, painful swallowing, vomiting blood, black stools, or unintentional weight loss?
P: No blood, no black poop. Swallow okay. Weight… maybe up two kilos. Too much staff meal, haha.
D: Cough at night and hoarseness in the morning, you said. Any wheezing or asthma?
P: No asthma. Just this tickle cough, especially after hot pot nights.
D: What foods or drinks make it worse? Spicy, fatty, tomato, citrus, chocolate, mint, caffeine, alcohol?
P: Eh… guilty, la. Chili oil my best friend. Taste spoon after spoon. Tomato braise, vinegar, black bean, all day. Espresso shots at 4 pm, sometimes 8 pm. Nighttime beer with my cooks, maybe two. Mint candy after service—make breath fresh for guests.
D: Do you eat late and go to bed soon after?
P: Service ends 10:30. I clean, nibble leftovers 11:30. Home 12, sleep 1 am. Like fast stir-fry, no rest time.
D: Any medications like ibuprofen? Do you smoke?
P: No smoke. Ibuprofen maybe once a week when back sore. Mostly I do ginger tea, baking soda in warm water. Old trick from Ma.
D: Understood. Any medical problems, surgeries, or family history of heart disease?
P: Me, nothing big. Father high pressure. Mother stomach “hot air,” she say. No surgeries.
D: I’ll check your vitals and do an exam now.
P: Okay, doc.
D: Your blood pressure and heartbeat are fine. Lungs clear. Abdomen a little tender in the upper middle, no red flags. Given your symptoms, this sounds like gastroesophageal reflux—acid coming up into the esophagus.
P: 嗯, like soup boiling over the pot edge, ah?
D: Exactly. We also need to be safe about the heart. I’d like an EKG today. If that’s normal and your pain stays the same pattern, we’ll treat this as reflux.
P: Can. My wife will sleep better if you check the wires.
D: Good. For reflux, I recommend a medicine called a proton pump inhibitor—omeprazole—once daily, 30 minutes before breakfast, for 8 weeks. We can add an alginate after meals for breakthrough symptoms.
P: Pill before breakfast, got it. The alginate is like… seaweed foam?
D: Yes, it forms a raft to keep acid down.
P: Nice. Raft for the soup. I like.
D: Lifestyle changes will help a lot:
- Avoid eating within 3 hours of bed.
- Smaller portions; avoid trigger foods—spicy chili, tomato, citrus, chocolate, mint, fatty foods, caffeine, alcohol—especially late.
- Elevate the head of your bed 6–8 inches.
- Loosen tight belts or aprons.
- Limit ibuprofen; use acetaminophen instead when possible.
- Aim for a few pounds of weight loss if you can.
P: Wah, chili is my soul. But maybe day time only? Night I switch to mild—ginger, scallion, soy. Espresso… I cut to one before noon. Beer, okay, I change to warm tea. Mint candy I stop.
D: That’s perfect. Also, consider a symptom diary: what you ate, when, and any heartburn. It helps identify personal triggers.
P: I’ll make a little “chef’s log.” Like inventory but for my stomach.
D: During service, try tasting smaller amounts and earlier. You can delegate late-night sauce checks to your sous-chef.
P: He’s ready. I’ll train his tongue. I spit more, swallow less for tastings. Not elegant, but functional, la.
D: Great. Any stress management? Even 5-minute breathing between dinner rush and cleanup can help.
P: I do three deep breaths by the walk-in fridge. Cold air wakes the brain. I’ll make it five.
D: If you develop trouble swallowing, vomiting blood, black stools, chest pain that feels different or occurs with exertion, severe shortness of breath, or fainting—seek urgent care.
P: Copy. If fire becomes thunder, I call 911, no hero.
D: We’ll do the EKG now. If normal, start omeprazole tomorrow. I’ll also give you an as-needed alginate. Follow up in 6–8 weeks. If symptoms persist, we may consider an endoscopy.
P: Doc, can still do family hot pot Saturday?
D: Yes—go lighter on spice, avoid late-night broth, keep your head elevated afterward, and stop eating at least three hours before bed.
P: Okay. Family time is like slow-cooked broth—needs patience. I’ll be patient with this stomach too.
D: I’ll print a simple guide and a Cantonese handout. Any other questions?
P: One more—my garden chilies looking at me very sad.
D: Keep growing them. Just enjoy them earlier in the day, smaller amounts, and not every day while we heal.
P: Deal. 多謝, doctor. You saved me and my chilies.
D: You’re welcome. Let’s get that EKG and set you up with the medications. See you in a few weeks.
P: 唔該晒. I go build the raft and calm the soup.
</dialogue>

P: Ah, doc, long time no see. You know, like how when ingredients sit too long, they start to lose flavor? My wife says that about me, getting older and less flavorful from no check-ups. 
D: Well, Liang, good to see you too. What brings you here today? You've been putting off visits for quite a while.
P: Yeah, no time, you know? Restaurant keeps me on toes. But, got some... what you call those burn feelings in chest? Heartburn, right? Comes after eating, like too much oil on wok, burning all the time.
D: Heartburn, that's correct. So, you're experiencing it frequently, and how long has this been going on?
P: Several months now. At first, thought maybe too spicy food, like my homegrown chili peppers. But it's been more often, sometimes during work, even when I haven't eaten. My wife, worried sick.
D: Have you noticed any particular triggers, like certain foods that make it worse?
P: Hmm, hard to say. Maybe rich sauces? We use a lot of sesame oil, but it's also what customers like. Could be stress too; running a restaurant, always fire in the kitchen. 
D: Stress is definitely a factor. And what about chest pain? How would you describe it?
P: Ah, like needle poking here and there. Not stabbing or anything, but enough I notice. Worries me because what if heart no strong like it used to? Have to think of family.
D: I understand your concerns, Liang. We'll take some steps to figure out what's going on. Based on what you've told me, it sounds like it could be a case of GERD, gastroesophageal reflux disease. Have you heard of that?
P: Ah, yes, I think. Stomach juices go wrong way up? Like when I cook soup, and sometimes it boils over. You're saying my digestive is like a soup boiling too high.
D: That's a creative way to look at it. We'll start by adjusting your diet and maybe some medication to help manage symptoms. No more ignoring the heartburn, okay?
P: Okay, okay. Thank you, doc. Guess it's time to take care of myself, not just the soup. Life is like slow-cooked broth, it needs patience, right?
D: That's wise, Liang. Let's make sure you're simmering at a healthy low for a long time.
P: Yes, yes, for the family. Thank you.
</dialogue>

P: Doctor, ni hao. I’m Liang, you know—head chef, home kitchen still calling my name when I walk in hospital corridors. These days the burn from my chest feels like a wok that won’t quiet down.
D: Nice to meet you, Liang. I’m Dr. Chen. Tell me more about the chest discomfort. When did you first notice it, and what does it feel like?
P: It’s like spice on a slow burner—not a sharp knife, more a warm pressure, sometimes in the center, sometimes spreading a bit. Mostly after big meals, especially at night when I’m thinking about the next service.
D: Any associated symptoms—burping, regurgitation, trouble swallowing, shortness of breath, or pain radiating to your arm or jaw?
P: Regurgitation, yes. I taste the flavors of today’s broth coming back up into my throat. Not sharp pain, but a heavy, unwelcoming sigh. And I worry a little about my chest at times when I push through a long service.
D: Have you noticed heartburn occurring after fatty meals, caffeine, alcohol, or lying flat?
P: Oh, all of the above like a spice parade. Fatty dishes, a couple of strong teas, a glass of wine—my wife says “too much bragging about your chili peppers.” Sometimes I sleep with an extra pillow, but still it climbs.
D: Do you have any trouble at night waking with reflux or choking sensation?
P: Sometimes I wake, yes. It’s like the doorbell rings in the middle of a busy dinner rush. I tell myself, “slow down, lung, stomach, heart, all of you.”
D: Any history of heart disease in your family, Liang? And do you smoke or use tobacco?
P: Family has stories, not a lot of heart drama, but I know the kitchen can hide heat. I quit smoking years ago—grew up, learned discipline. I drink less than I used to, but the appetite for life is still large.
D: Do you take any antacids or remedies at home? Any NSAIDs, like ibuprofen?
P: I’ve kept some home remedies—ginger tea, a tiny sip of warm water with honey. Antacids help a bit, but not the full cure. I avoid heavy medicines, prefer natural stuff when possible.
D: Any weight change, fatigue, or trouble with digestion besides heartburn?
P: Weight is steady enough; I still cook big dinners. But I feel tired after long kitchen shifts, chest a bit heavy, knees not liking the pace as much as before.
D: Okay. Based on what you described, GERD is likely, with chest discomfort that needs assessment to rule out other causes. I’d like to do a physical exam and maybe an ECG, plus some basic labs. How does that sound?
P: It sounds like a plan, doctor. My family wants me around for many more hot pots. If tests help me breathe easy again, I’ll take them in stride.
D: I’ll arrange an ECG today and a basic blood panel. If needed, we can discuss a trial of acid suppression therapy and lifestyle changes. Do you mind if we talk about those now?
P: Give me the recipe, doctor. I’ll listen to steps and chop them into my day. Diet tweaks, timing, waking early for digestion—tell me how to mix this well.
D: First, meal timing matters. Try not to lie down within 2–3 hours after eating. Elevate the head of your bed a bit. Second, identify trigger foods—spicy dishes, fatty foods, chocolate, caffeine, alcohol—and reduce them. Third, consider smaller, more frequent meals rather than one big banquet.
P: That’s a chef’s map, alright. Smaller plates, more pauses between courses. I can do that—my kitchen talks to me in rhythm.
D: In terms of meds, we can start with a proton pump inhibitor, like omeprazole, once daily before breakfast for 4–8 weeks if symptoms persist. We’ll reassess. Any concerns about taking medicine regularly?
P: I worry about long-term use, but I trust you. If it helps me keep my family’s pot of love simmering, I’ll try it.
D: We’ll monitor for side effects and adjust as needed. Also, if chest discomfort worsens or you have fainting, sweating, or severe pain, seek urgent care.
P: Understood. I’ll be mindful. One more thing—my kids worry I push too hard. I want to keep working, but not at the expense of my health.
D: Balancing work and health is important. We’ll schedule follow-ups and possibly a referral to a nutritionist or gastroenterologist if symptoms don’t improve.
P: Thank you, doctor. If life is a slow-cooked broth, I’ll add patience and a better recipe for my heart. I’m ready to start.
D: Good. I’ll order the tests now and start you on a plan. We’ll take care of you—one comforting pot at a time.
P: And if the pots could talk, they’d say “stay strong, slow and steady.” Let’s go. 

</dialogue>

P: Doctor, ni hao. I usually no like to come doctor, you know, prefer fix at home—ginger tea, small bowl of rice porridge. But my wife, she worried, say maybe serious, ah. Chest pain come like this—sometimes burning, sometimes more like slow fire in belly, stopped me cooking good for family. I want to know, what’s going on? 
D: Hello, Mr. Wang. Thank you for coming in today. I understand it’s not always easy to see a doctor, but it’s good you came. Can you tell me more about your chest discomfort? When does the heartburn usually occur?
P: Ah, it’s tricky. Usually after big meals, late night after work, especially when I eat spicy food or drink tea—I love my chili peppers, cannot lie. Even standing long time in kitchen, sometimes feel that burn like heat from wok, but inside here. Sometimes chest feel tight, but never really pain like angry dragon, more like slow simmer. 
D: It sounds like classic heartburn symptoms. Do you also have acid regurgitation or difficulty swallowing?
P: Acid come up sometimes, very sour, make me cough little. Swallowing no problem, still clear as mountain stream. But these things happen too often now, affect my sleep, makes me tired next day. Like broth cooked too fast, no flavor, no strength. 
D: Have you noticed anything that makes the symptoms better or worse?
P: Yes, doctor. Lying down right after eat, bad idea. This one make the fire hotter. Sitting up, waiting, small walk, ginger water—little better. But when busy, no time for all these careful things; fire just grow. Also, sometimes after big meetings with staff, stress come like storm, cannot help faster heartburn. 
D: That makes sense. Stress and certain foods can aggravate GERD. From your description, it sounds like you have gastroesophageal reflux disease. I’d like to do some examination and suggest lifestyle adjustments and medication to reduce the acid.
P: GERD? Ah, that name sound big, but if medicine can help, I listen. I worry long term—my cooking, my family... If I cannot do hot pot dinners or tend my garden, life lose big joy. What lifestyle changes you think? Should I stop eating spicy chili? 
D: Not necessarily stop, but reducing spicy and fatty foods is a good start. Also, avoid late meals, elevate your head when sleeping, and try to reduce stress. I can also prescribe you medicine to reduce stomach acid which should help the burning and prevent damage.
P: Okay, okay... I want to try. This cooking life is like slow-cooked broth: need patience and care. I learn to be patient with my health too. But doctor, will these medicines make me weak? I no want lose strength to stand kitchen long hours. 
D: The medicines are designed to help heal your esophagus and reduce discomfort. They won’t make you weak. In fact, by managing the symptoms you may find you have more energy. It’s important for your work and family.
P: Sounds good. My wife will be happy to hear this. She always say “Liang, you chef king, but body must strong like mountain.” I will try eat better, sleep better, and take medicine. Thank you, doctor, for listening. 
D: You’re very welcome, Mr. Wang. Remember, health is just like cooking: balance and care are key. Let’s schedule a follow-up in a few weeks to see how you’re doing. If symptoms worsen or new ones appear, come back sooner, okay?
P: Will do. I respect doctor advice. Maybe this time, not wait for wife’s scold, come check earlier next time. Life slow broth, important every step. Thank you again. 
D: Take care, Mr. Wang. I’m here to help you stay healthy for your family and your kitchen. 
P: Xièxiè, doctor. I feel better already.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, um, do I sit here? Or on this spot? Oh! I brought my robot doodle in case I get bored.
D: Hi Emma! You can sit wherever you're comfy. That’s a very cool drawing! What’s your robot’s name?
P: Thanks! It’s Flexi—‘cause he can bend all the way backwards and do a flip. I wish I could do that—except maybe just a little, since flips make me dizzy. 
D: Flexi sounds awesome. So, your mom told me you’ve had a bit more coughing and wheezing lately, especially at night. Can you tell me what that’s been like?
P: Um, sometimes when I’m lying down, I feel this scratchy spot in my throat, and then it’s like—*cough-cough*—over and over, even when I really try not to. Last night it happened, and I had to sit up and hug my pillow for a long time. Then I could finally sleep. But it’s been happening two days, I think? Or maybe three.
D: That doesn’t sound fun. Have you had trouble running or playing, too?
P: Mmm-hmm. At recess I was playing space explorers with Daniel, and my chest got all tight and squeaky. I had to just watch for a while, and Lucy was sad ‘cause she wanted me to chase her. I don’t like to stop if I’m almost done with the rocket ship game.
D: I bet that’s frustrating. Do you remember if you used your inhaler when it happened?
P: Yeah. Mom says to do two puffs, so I did, and it helped a little. But my throat felt weird like a frog was living in it. It’s not *funny* like when I do robot voices, just annoying.
D: I see. Have you noticed if anything in particular makes it worse? Like playing outside, or dust, or maybe if someone is cleaning?
P: Um, outside sometimes, but also when I’m laughing a lot, like the day Daniel told his potato joke. Oh! And when Mom vacuums the big rug. It makes me sneeze and then my breathing gets all tiny for a bit.
D: Thank you for telling me that, Emma. That’s helpful. Have you or your mom noticed any fevers, or has your nose been running a lot?
P: I don’t think so. Sometimes I get a little stuffy, but mostly it’s just the cough and the wheezy-squeaky part. I don’t feel hot—I checked with Mom’s forehead tester. She lets me beep everyone when they’re sick.
D: Good for you. It sounds like you’re already a little doctor! Can you show me how you breathe when you get the tight feeling?
P: Okay, so I go—*takes a big breath, then squeaks out a wheezy exhale*—like that. It feels like my chest is wearing a super tight robot suit.
D: That does sound tough. Are you feeling that way right now, or just sometimes?
P: Right now I’m okay, maybe just tired. But this morning it was hard when I raced Lucy to the mailbox. She beat me! But I let her win, a little. 
D: You’re a good big sister. I want to listen to your breathing now, okay? Deep breaths for me…
P: *breathes in and out a few times, giggles* The stethoscope’s always so cold! 
D: Sorry about that! All done. You did great. I think your asthma is acting up, especially at night. I’ll talk to your mom about maybe changing your medicine a little, so you won’t have to miss playing anymore. Does that sound good?
P: Yes, please! I just want to fix it like I fix my robots. Can you put in a super battery or something? Or maybe an ‘anti-cough circuit’!
D: I wish it were that easy! But we can give you something to help, and your mom and I will make a plan. Do you have any questions about your asthma or the medicine?
P: Um…will it make me sleepy? Sometimes I get sleepy from cough syrup and I don’t like missing story time. And…can I still play outside if I wear my hoodie? Even if it’s cold?
D: Good questions. The medicine shouldn’t make you sleepy, and you can still play outside! We just want to make sure you have your inhaler and take breaks if you start getting wheezy. And your hoodie is a great idea.
P: Okay! And…can I show you how my robot Flexi does his flip before I go? He’s actually a pop-it toy but I drew rocket boosters on him.
D: I would love to see that, Emma.
P: Watch! *makes Flexi somersault across her lap* Ta-da! See? If I could do that, asthma would never catch me.
D: That’s amazing. I have a feeling you and Flexi are both going to do great. Thanks for visiting, Emma.
P: Thanks, Dr. Lee! Bye! I’m gonna tell Mom that I did the ‘deep breath’ test like a champ.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Doctor. I’m Emma Broussard. I’m seven. I love inventing games with my sister Lucy and brother Daniel, and I like fixing old tablets and toy robots.
D: Hello, Emma. I’m Dr. Patel. Nice to meet you. Your mom told me you’ve been coughing more at night and you missed recess—let’s see what we can do to help you get back to playing.
P: Yeah. When I run around the yard with Daniel, my chest gets tight and I wheeze a little. At night I cough a lot and I wake up sometimes.
D: That sounds rough. We’ll listen to your lungs, check your breathing, and go over how you use your inhaler. Is your mom here with you today?
P: Yes, she’s outside with Lucy. She helps me a lot and wants me to stay healthy so I can keep inventing and fixing things.
D: Great. We’ll ask her a few questions about when your cough happens, how you sleep, and if you have allergies. We’ll also check your inhaler technique and spacer use if you have one.
P: I sometimes need my rescue inhaler after I run and I can’t catch my breath. I know I should breathe out slowly after pressing it. I try to use the spacer when I have one.
D: We’ll watch you use the inhaler and practice. It’s normal to feel a little frustrated when it doesn’t work right away—but we’ll get you set.
P: I do get frustrated. But I still love science and fixing gadgets. I want to go back to recess and race Daniel, and I want to keep drawing robots in my sketchbook.
D: We’ll aim to improve your nighttime symptoms and exercise tolerance. We might add a daily controller inhaler to help prevent nighttime coughing and make breathing easier during activities. We’ll also talk about triggers like cold air, dust, pets, and how to avoid them.
P: That sounds good. I like drawing while we wait and I hope you like my robot pictures.
D: Great. We’ll prepare an asthma action plan for school and family, and we’ll schedule a follow-up in 4 to 6 weeks to see how you’re doing. If anything changes, you can call us.
P: Okay. Thanks, Doctor. I hope I can run around again soon and keep building gadgets.
D: You’re welcome, Emma. We’ll get you back to the robots and the races as soon as we can.

</dialogue>

P: Hi. I’m Emma. My chest’s been squeaky at night, like a tiny harmonica.
D: Hi, Emma. I’m Dr. Wells. Thanks for telling me. When did the squeaky sounds start getting worse?
P: Um… like two weeks ago? Maybe three. It’s worse when I lie down.
D: Got it. Do you cough more at night or during the day?
P: Night. I cough and then I need water and then I cough again. It’s annoying.
D: Have you needed to use your inhaler more often?
P: The blue one? Yeah. I used it at school twice this week and at bedtime maybe… four times?
D: Do you use a spacer with it?
P: The tube thingy? Yep. I click it on and do ten slow breaths like the nurse showed me. I counted.
D: Excellent technique. Any wheezing or tightness when you run or play?
P: Yes. Recess tag got me all huffy. I had to sit on the bench. I didn’t like that.
D: I bet that was frustrating. Any colds or sniffles recently?
P: My sister had a drippy nose. I kind of had it, but mostly just the cough.
D: Do you notice triggers, like dust, pets, or when you’re around smoke?
P: We don’t smoke. My grandma’s cat makes my nose itch, though. And the classroom had chalk dust on Friday and it smelled dusty.
D: How about weather changes or pollen? It’s been a bit breezy lately.
P: When the air feels pokey—like dry and cold—I cough more. Also when I run after Daniel.
D: Understandable. Do you take any daily controller medicine, like a white or orange inhaler?
P: I have a white one at home. Mom says two puffs morning, two puffs night. I forget sometimes because my toothbrush sings and I dance.
D: That toothbrush can be very distracting. About how many times did you miss it this week?
P: Maybe… two mornings. One night. Sorry.
D: No need to be sorry. We just want to help you breathe easy. Any nighttime wake-ups this week?
P: Three nights. I woke up and listened to my own lungs. They sounded like robot crickets.
D: Any chest pain?
P: More like squeezing. Not sharp. I can still talk, but I don’t want to.
D: Have you been to the ER or needed oral steroids lately?
P: No ER. I don’t like those bright lights. No pink medicine either.
D: Good. Any activities you’ve skipped besides recess?
P: I didn’t race Daniel yesterday. I worked on my robot sketch instead.
D: I’d like to listen to your lungs now. Big breaths in and out, okay?
P: Okay. Like blowing up a balloon?
D: Exactly. In… and out. Again. Good job. I hear a little wheeze at the bases, but air is moving well.
P: Is that bad?
D: It means your asthma is a bit active, but we can get it under control. Do you know your asthma plan colors—green, yellow, red?
P: Green is good, yellow is “be careful,” red is “mom says we go now.”
D: Perfect. I think you’ve been in the yellow zone at night. We’ll tune up your plan. Would you be okay using your controller inhaler every morning and night, no misses, for the next few weeks?
P: I can tape a note to my toothbrush. Or put a sticker on my robot box.
D: Great idea. Also use your blue inhaler 15 minutes before recess or running, two puffs with spacer. That may prevent the wheeze.
P: Pre-boost! Like charging my battery.
D: Exactly. If you’re still coughing at night after a week of perfect use, we may adjust the dose. Sound good?
P: Yep. I want to play tag again.
D: Any heart racing or jitters when you use the blue inhaler?
P: My hands get a little buzzy, but it goes away. I don’t mind.
D: That can happen and it’s okay. Do you sleep with lots of stuffed animals?
P: I have five. Well… seven. They guard me.
D: Let’s let two guard the bed and keep the others on a shelf to cut down dust. Also, wash bedding weekly in hot water if you can.
P: I can tell Mom. I can help. I like pressing the washer buttons.
D: For school, I’ll write a note so you can use your inhaler before recess and have it available with the nurse. Is your spacer at school?
P: No, it lives in the kitchen. I can bring the purple one to school.
D: Perfect. Any questions for me?
P: Can I still run if I do the pre-boost? And can I go to the birthday party at the trampoline place?
D: Yes to both, as long as you pre-treat with two puffs and your symptoms are controlled. Bring your inhaler and spacer.
P: Okay. Also, do robots get asthma?
D: Only if they forget to change their filters. You’ll change yours by using your controller every day.
P: Ha. I’ll be a clean-filter robot.
D: Love it. If you have coughing more than two nights a week, need your blue inhaler more than two days a week, or can’t play like usual, that’s a sign to call us.
P: Two and two. Got it.
D: I’ll print your updated asthma action plan and a school form. We’ll see you in four weeks to check in, sooner if you’re in the red zone.
P: Thanks, Dr. Wells. I’m gonna win at tag again.
D: I believe it. Breathe easy, Emma.
</dialogue>

P: Hi there! Is this where I need to go for my doctor's visit?
D: Hello Emma! Yes, that’s right. Let Dr. Green take a look at you today. How are you feeling?
P: Um, usually just fine but lately, I feel achy and tired when I try to run around with the other kids at recess.
D: That must be hard for you, isn’t it? Well, let’s see what we can do to make things better for playing times!
P: Okay! But will this mean no more tablets or robot toys from here on out?
D: Nope! We’ll figure out how to help your breathing get better and strong for all the activities you love.
P: I hope so. It makes me sad when I have to sit at the benches instead of joining everyone else.
D: I understand that, Emma. Let’s make sure your inhaler is working properly and we might discuss adjusting it if needed.
P: What if it doesn’t work? Will I still be able to fix broken things?
D: Of course you can! We’ll find a way for you to enjoy those activities without worrying about breathing troubles.
P: Great, because sometimes the robots need fixing right away!
D: That’s quite true. Can you tell me more about how your chest feels when you play and during bedtime, sweetie?
P: It gets tight and makes wheezing sounds, especially if I stay up late coloring with my markers or playing on tablets that don’t work well.
D: So those times are tough for breathing?
P: Yeah! And sometimes mom has to come get me from school because of it. But she works a lot too, so it’s not good for her.
D: Thank you for telling me. We’ll work together with your mother to make sure that doesn’t happen much anymore, okay? Would you like to show the doctor some of your sketches?
P: Sure! I drew cool robot friends and fun places they explore in my dreams.
D: That looks amazing! You’re so creative and talented, Emma.


P: Mom, is it time for me to explain everything to Dr. Green now?
</dialogue>

P: Hi Dr. Lee! It's nice to see you again. How are you today?
D: Hello, Leah! I heard your mom tell me that you're having some trouble with your asthma lately.
P: Yeah, sometimes it feels like I can't breathe when I run around at school during gym class. But my imaginary friends in the playground help keep my spirits up!
D: That's a wonderful way to stay positive, Leah. Your mom mentioned you’ve been wheezing more often too?
P: Uh-huh, and I have to stop sometimes when we’re outside just playing or if it's cold out.
D: Can you tell me about your coughing episode in class? Did anything trigger it like smoke or dust?
P: Well, it was really loud in the gym, with all the clanging of equipment. It kind of felt like magic potions were swirling around my chest and making me giggle, but then... poof! Out came a cough.
D: Those are some very creative descriptions, Leah. Does your asthma usually get worse at certain times, say when you run or laugh really hard?
P: Oh yeah, especially running for the bus in the morning. My legs feel like they’re trying to race clouds which isn’t easy!
D: It sounds like we might need to adjust your inhaler. I want to check if a stronger strength would be better for managing those episodes.
P: Can my imaginary friends also take medicine sometimes? They get tired too you know?
D: Of course! We can pretend they have special health potions just like you. And Leah, remember, telling me about how your breathing feels helps us make your day easier and happier.
P: Okay, I'll do that!
D: Great girl! Are there any other questions or worries you want to share with Dr. Lee today?
P: Can my medicine be a potion flavor soon? Maybe something like a fruity rainbow one?
D: That would be fun, Leah! Your imagination and creativity are great.

The doctor’s visit continues smoothly as the pediatrician reviews Leah's medical history and physical condition, while staying attentive to her unique perspective on health through her imaginative world.
</dialogue>

P: Um… hi. My name’s Leah. 
D: Hello, Leah! It’s nice to meet you. I see you brought your sketchbook—do you like to draw?
P: Oh! Yeah. I drew a dragon with pink wings last night and my little sister says it’s the queen of clouds. Sorry, um, my mom told me to talk about my breathing…
D: That’s okay, you can tell me anything you like. Are you having more trouble breathing when you play, Leah?
P: Sometimes, yeah. If I run around in the playground, I feel like there’s a squirrel sitting on my chest and it’s hard to catch my breath. My chest squeaks, too, and I’ve been coughing more. 
D: I hear you. That sounds uncomfortable! Does your inhaler help when that happens?
P: Sometimes. If I take two puffs, I feel less squeaky, but not always all the way better. Sometimes I have to stop playing tag, and I really wanted to be the wizard in our game last week but had to sit out. 
D: That’s frustrating, I bet. When does this happen most—when you run, or sometimes even at rest?
P: Mostly when I’m running or jumping outside, or in gym class. It happened during dodgeball and everyone stared at me, so I tried to pretend it wasn’t bad. But then my teacher let me go to the nurse.
D: Thank you for telling me, Leah. Do you ever wake up at night coughing or having trouble breathing?
P: Not always, but I did twice last week. I used my inhaler and then hugged my stuffed bunny until I wasn’t scared. 
D: Do you notice anything that makes your asthma worse? Like cold air, dust, or pets?
P: Cold air makes me cough for sure. We don’t have pets, but my grandma’s cat makes me sneeze. Sometimes when my brother brings in leaves, it’s itchy in my nose.
D: I see. Have you used your inhaler more often than usual lately?
P: Um, yes. More this week than before. Mom writes it down. I think it’s lots—my big sister helped me count.
D: Thank you, Leah. You’re doing a great job explaining. May I listen to your breathing now? I promise it won’t hurt.
P: Okay… Can I hold my sketchbook while you do it? It makes me brave.
D: Of course! Hold it tight. Deep breath in for me… and out. Good job. Again, please…
P: It feels funny having someone listen to all the noises. Will my lungs ever sound like a song? Like at church?
D: That’s a wonderful thought! We want your breathing to be as smooth and easy as possible, like a gentle song. I think we can help with that. Would you like to help decide what makes you feel better?
P: Yes, please! I wanna play and not always have to sit out. And, um, not be scared if people look at me.
D: Absolutely. I’m glad you told me. We’ll talk about some ways to help—not just medicine, but also things to do before playing. Would you like to draw me a picture of what it feels like when you can’t breathe well?
P: Sure! I’m drawing a windy tornado with a little girl holding on tight. But maybe I’ll draw her riding a dragon next time, because then she can fly anywhere.
D: I love that idea. Thank you for being so helpful and brave, Leah. You’re an excellent artist and a great storyteller. Let’s make a good plan together—sound good?
P: Yeah! And maybe if my breathing gets better, I can be the wizard next time we play. Wizards aren’t scared of anything!
</dialogue>

P: Hi.
D: Hi Leah — I'm Dr. Kim. Your mom told me you've been wheezing when you play outside. I also heard you like to draw — did you bring anything today?
P: I did. It's a dragon that coughs and sneezes stars. He has a tiny crown.
D: I love that. Can you tell me when you started having trouble breathing and coughing?
P: A few weeks ago. When we play outside at recess or run for the castle games my chest feels tight, like somebody zipped my shirt too small.
D: Does it happen every time you run or only some days?
P: Not every time. Mostly when I run a lot. Last week in gym I had a big coughing fit and my teacher made me sit.
D: How often would you say — once a week, a few times a week, or more?
P: Umm... maybe three times a week? And sometimes at night I wake up coughing one or two times.
D: Do you have an inhaler with you? What do you call it?
P: I have a blue puff. My mom keeps it in my backpack. I use it when my chest gets tight.
D: Do you take any other medicine every day?
P: My mom gives me a little white puff sometimes in the morning, but I forget a lot because I'm drawing. My big sister reminds me.
D: Do you notice things that make it worse — like dogs, pollen, cold wind, or dust?
P: When my friend brings her dog, my nose itches. In spring my eyes get scratchy. Cold wind makes me breathe funny too.
D: Does anyone at school know about your asthma? Are you able to use your inhaler there?
P: My teacher knows. I usually wait for my sister because I feel shy using it in front of kids.
D: That's okay. Can I listen to your breathing? Take big, slow breaths for me — like you're blowing up a big balloon for your dragon.
P: Okay. 
D: Thank you. I can hear a little wheeze when you breathe out, which means your asthma is more active right now.
P: Does that mean I'm sick?
D: Not like a fever or a cold — it's your asthma acting up. We can help it so you can run and play without coughing. I'm thinking we should add a daily medicine to calm the airways and keep the blue puff for quick help.
P: Will the new medicine make me sleepy? Or make me look different?
D: It shouldn't make you sleepy or change how you look. Lots of kids use a daily medicine so they can play without trouble. It's pretty safe.
P: I don't want kids to laugh. Will they laugh at my inhaler?
D: Many kids use inhalers — it's normal. If you want, I can send a note to your teacher so they know exactly when you should use it and can help.
P: Can I still be the queen of our forts? I have to lead the battles.
D: Absolutely. We'll give you a plan: use the daily medicine every morning as your shield, and the blue puff as your quick defender. You can also use the blue before gym if you know you'll be running a lot.
P: Does the inhaler really fight the wheeze dragon?
D: Yes. The blue one helps quickly when the wheeze dragon attacks. The daily medicine helps keep the dragon sleepy so it doesn't attack as often.
P: My sister says spacers help. Can I have one?
D: Yes — a spacer makes it easier to get the medicine into your lungs. Let's practice: put the spacer in your mouth, breathe out, I'll press the puff, and then take five slow breaths.
P: Okay. 
D: That was great — you breathed in slowly and calmly. If you rinse your mouth after the daily medicine it helps too.
P: Will it taste weird?
D: Maybe a little like medicine, but the spacer helps and a quick rinse makes it fine.
P: Can I still have cookies and watch movies with my mom?
D: Of course. Keep doing the fun things. Try to stay away from smoke and if pollen is high maybe play inside for a bit.
P: What if the blue puff doesn't help?
D: If the blue puff doesn't help and you have trouble talking, very fast breathing, or your lips or face look different, go to the emergency room right away. Otherwise, keep the rescue inhaler with you and call us if things don't improve.
P: Will you tell my teacher how to help?
D: Yes — I'll write an asthma action plan for you and send a note to your school so they know when to use the inhaler and when to call us.
P: Thank you. Can I draw you a picture? I can share my crayons.
D: I'd love that. One more thing — we'll start the daily medicine today, give you a spacer, and I'll check on you in about four weeks to see how it's going. If cost is a worry, we'll find a low-cost option so you can get it.
P: Okay. I feel better. Can we go outside and play now? My dragon is waiting.
D: Yes — go play, and remember your shield in the morning and your blue puff if you get tight. Bring your next drawing to the follow-up, okay?
P: I will. Bye, Dr. Kim. I drew you with a cookie hat.
D: Bye, Leah — see you soon, and keep being the brave queen of your forts.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Doctor! I brought my drawing book today. I was gonna show you my newest picture of a dragon and a unicorn having a tea party in a big enchanted forest! 
D: That’s wonderful, Leah! I’d love to see your drawing. How have you been feeling lately? 
P: Well, I’ve been okay, but… when I run around outside, I get tired and my chest feels weird sometimes. Like, I want to breathe but it’s all tight and makes me wheeze. 
D: I see. Has this been happening more often, especially when you play? 
P: Yeah. Even more than before. Like, during recess and when I play soccer with my brothers. Yesterday, I had a big coughing fit after gym class. I thought I might not be able to play anymore. 
D: That sounds uncomfortable. And your mom says you’ve had more wheezing too? 
P: Uh-huh. It’s like my breath is playing hide-and-seek, and I can’t catch it. Sometimes I get scared, but I try to remember my breathing tricks. Mom says I have to tell you if I feel worse. 
D: That’s very brave of you, Leah. And it’s important we work together to make sure you can run and play without feeling that way. Have you used your asthma inhaler recently? 
P: Just once or twice, but not really during the wheezing. I forget sometimes, especially if I’m busy drawing or playing pretend with my little sister. 
D: It’s okay to forget, but I want to check if your inhaler is still good and see if we need to change your medicine a little. Would that be okay? 
P: Yes, please. I want to feel strong and be able to chase my imaginary dragons again. 
D: I’ll make sure of that. And Leah, it’s great that you’re so creative and brave. We’ll help your lungs be as healthy as your drawings are colorful. 
P: Thanks, Doctor! I like when my lungs aren’t all squeaky and tired. Then I can go on more adventures.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Harper. My name’s Dr. Lawson. It’s nice to meet you. How are you feeling today?
H: Um… hi. I’m okay, I guess. My tummy hurts a little. Mom said it’s alright though.
D: I’m glad you came to see me so we can talk about what’s bothering you. Can you tell me more about your tummy? Does it hurt all the time, or only sometimes?
H: It’s… mostly before I have to go to school. Or if I don’t know what’s going to happen next. Sometimes it feels twisty. Like, if it’s too loud or if we have something different, like a substitute teacher.
D: That sounds uncomfortable. Has it been happening for a long time?
H: Maybe… since the beginning of school, I think? Sometimes I get scared if we have fire drills too. My heart beats super fast and I want to hide.
D: I see. When your tummy hurts or when you feel scared, what do you do to help yourself feel better?
H: Umm. I like to sit real close to my teacher. Or I squeeze Mr. Cat—my stuffed kitty—if I can have him. If I’m home, I find Mama or Daddy. Or I just… I have to cry for a little bit.
D: That makes sense. It’s good you know things that can help you feel safer. Can you tell me about sleeping? Is it hard to fall asleep lately?
H: Yeah. Sometimes I can’t stop thinking about what’s gonna happen the next day. Like if I’ll forget my backpack, or if I’ll lose something. I ask Mama if she’ll sit with me for a while, and Daddy reads stories, but I still worry. I wake up a lot.
D: That must be so hard, sweetie. Has anything scary happened at school, or do you feel worried about something there?
H: Umm… I don’t like when it’s group time. Everybody is noisy. And some kids push in line, or laugh really loud. I’m scared maybe I’ll get something wrong and people will look at me. But… my friend Lily lets me sit with her, so that helps.
D: You’re very brave to talk about these things with me, Harper. Do you remember a time when your tummy felt better or when you were extra happy at school?
H: Oh! When we did drawing day. I got to make a horse and it was quiet, just me and two other kids. And on library day, when I read books with Ms. Patch, I felt safe.
D: I love that you enjoy drawing. If you could change something about your day at school to help you feel better, what would you wish for?
H: Maybe… more quiet times. And if I could have Mr. Cat with me. My teacher did let me bring a sticker once, from my sticker book. That felt good. Oh! And if someone would tell me what’s going to happen after, ‘cause surprises are scary.
D: That’s a great idea! Thank you for telling me all of this, Harper. I’m going to talk with your parents and teacher, and we’ll work together on ways to help you feel safer and more comfortable. Is there anything else you want to tell me?
H: Umm… do you have any cats here? Or maybe a squishy toy I can hold? That makes it easier to talk.
D: I don’t have a real cat, but I do have some little animal toys you can choose from. How about a squishy puppy?
H: Yes, please. Thank you. I like puppies too.
D: You’re very welcome. You did such a wonderful job being brave today, Harper.
H: Thank you. Um… can I go sit with Mama now?
D: Absolutely. Mama’s waiting right outside for you.
</dialogue>

P : Hi, Dr. Thompson, thanks for seeing us today. We've been worried about Harper lately.
D: Of course, what seems to be going on?
P : Well, Harper's been complaining about stomachaches and having trouble sleeping, and she's really scared about going to school.
D: Okay, I see. Harper, can you tell me a little bit about how you've been feeling lately?
P : I don't know... my tummy hurts sometimes, and I don't want to go to school 'cause I don't wanna be late, and I don't know what's gonna happen.
D: That sounds like a lot to worry about. Can you tell me what happens when you start feeling worried about school?
P : I don't know... I just feel yucky, and my heart beats fast, and I wanna stay home with Mommy.
D: Okay, sweetie. It sounds like you're feeling a little scared and unsure about school. That's okay, lots of kids feel that way. Can you tell me about something you like to do that makes you feel happy?
P : I like to draw pictures of my cat, Whiskers, and play with my brother.
D: That sounds like fun! Do you ever feel scared or worried when you're playing with your brother?
P : No... I feel happy when we're playing.
D: Okay, Harper. I think we might be able to help you feel better about school and about your worries. But first, I need to ask you some more questions, okay?
P : O-okay...
D: Can you tell me more about your tummy aches? When do they usually happen?
P : Uh... sometimes in the morning, before school... and sometimes when we're eating dinner.
D: Okay, I see. And what do you do when your tummy hurts?
P : I tell Mommy, and she gives me a hug and says everything will be okay.
D: That sounds like a great thing to do! Harper, I want you to know that it's okay to feel scared and worried, and it's okay to ask for help. We're going to work together to help you feel better, okay?
P : O-okay... thank you, Doctor.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, sugar. My name’s Dr. Reeves. What’s your name?
H: Um… I’m Harper. 
D: Hi, Harper. It’s nice to meet you. Thanks for coming in today. Your mom told me you’ve been having a lot of tummy aches lately. Can you tell me about that?
H: Sometimes my tummy hurts in the morning when I get up. It gets twisty. 
D: Oh, twisty, huh? That sounds uncomfortable. Does it happen at any other times besides in the morning?
H: Um…sometimes—like, before we go to school, or if we got, um, a fire drill. The noise makes me feel scared and then my tummy hurts more.
D: That sounds really tough. I know fire drills can be loud! Besides those times, does it hurt when you eat or after you eat?
H: Not really. Mostly it’s before school, or like, if we’re doing something new and I don’t know what’s gonna happen.
D: I see. When your tummy hurts, do you ever feel other things, like your heart beating fast, or like you can’t breathe very good?
H: Sometimes, yes. My heart goes thump-thump-thump, and my hands get sweaty. One time, I even cried in the bathroom so nobody would see me.
D: Thank you for telling me, Harper. That’s really brave. How about your sleep—has it been hard falling asleep or staying asleep at night?
H: I—I can’t fall asleep easy. I think about a lotta things, like, what if I forget my homework? Or what if my grandma’s cat, Buttons, gets lost?
D: Sounds like you have a lot of worries on your mind. And what helps you feel better when you’re scared or worried?
H: Um… I like to hug Mr. Whiskers—he’s my stuffed cat. And if my mom sings me the rainbow song, I sometimes feel a little better.
D: Stuffed animals can be the best helpers. Is it hard to say goodbye to your mom and dad in the morning?
H: Yes… I try not to cry, but sometimes I do, and my teacher lets me pick a sticker anyway. I just want my mom to stay with me till I’m okay.
D: That’s understandable. You know, lots of kids feel worried about school or even grown-ups about work. Would it be helpful if I showed your mom and dad ways to help your worries feel a little lighter?
H: Maybe… if she can make my tummy stop hurting, that’d be nice. Can I still draw cats and horses at home?
D: Of course you can, Harper. Drawing is a great way to help your feelings. I think that’s a wonderful idea.
H: Okay. Um, will I have to get a shot today?
D: No shots today, I promise. Just talking. And you did super great. Is there anything you want to ask me, or anything else you want to tell me about feeling worried?
H: Um… if I have lots of worries, does that mean I’m bad?
D: Oh, no, not at all, Harper. Worries happen to all of us sometimes, but you’re kind and smart and so very brave for talking about them. We’ll help you find ways to feel better, together.
H: Okay. Can I have a sticker too?
D: You bet. You earned it.
</dialogue>

P: Hi. My name is Harper. This is Mr. Whiskers. He likes the waiting room. He's been very brave.
D: Hi Harper, I’m Dr. Lane. It’s nice to meet you and Mr. Whiskers. How are you feeling today?
P: My tummy has been hurting a lot. It hurts more when it’s noisy at school. I don’t like the loud bells. They make my heart go fast.
D: I’m sorry your tummy hurts. When did your belly start feeling this way?
P: Umm...it started a few months. Sometimes before school I feel it, and sometimes when I have to do group things. I tell my teacher and she gives me a sticker, but it still hurts.
D: Do you get headaches or feel dizzy too?
P: Sometimes my head hurts. I feel all squishy and I want to hide under the table. I don’t like when my class counts us for attendance ‘cause I think I’ll be called on.
D: Do you worry about anything else? About things at home or at school?
P: I worry that I’ll lose my favorite crayon, or that I’ll forget my homework, or that my friends won’t like my drawings. Yesterday I thought maybe the teacher would be mad if I cried.
D: Do you cry a lot at school?
P: Not a lot. Sometimes I almost do. I get teary when someone shouts or when there’s a big change, like when we had a substitute teacher. Then I didn’t want to go in.
D: How are you sleeping, Harper?
P: I wake up a lot. I have dreams where I can’t find Mom. I keep Mr. Whiskers on my chest and that helps. I pray at bed and that makes it a little better.
D: Do you eat okay?
P: I eat dinner. Sometimes I don't feel like eating breakfast because my tummy feels funny. Mom makes pancakes and I like those.
D: Has anything big changed at home or school lately?
P: No. We still bake cookies on Sundays. But my teacher said the classroom will be rearranged soon and that makes me nervous.
D: Who do you tell when you feel scared?
P: I tell my mom. She rubs my back and says we can breathe together. Sometimes I tell my friend Lily and she gives me a sticker.
D: Do you worry about being away from your parents?
P: A little. I worry when Daddy works late. I think maybe the bus will forget me or I'll be the last in line.
D: Have you ever had medicine for how you’re feeling?
P: No. I don't want medicine unless it makes me less scared.
D: That’s okay. There are some things we can try before medicine. Would you like to hear some ideas to help your tummy and sleeping and school worries?
P: Yes. Please. I want my tummy to not hurt.
D: First, tummy aches from worry are common. We’ll try calming steps: when you feel your heart go fast, try “five-finger breaths.” Breathe in through your nose for five slow counts while tracing one finger, breathe out for five counts. You can practice with Mr. Whiskers.
P: I can do that. Mr. Whiskers likes breathing.
D: For bedtime, keep your routine—same time, quiet story, prayer, Mr. Whiskers near you. Try a small bedtime ritual like counting three happy things from your day.
P: I can think of three. Cookies, Daddy's stories, and Lily’s stickers.
D: Good ones. At school, we can make a plan with your teacher: a quiet corner you can go to if it gets too noisy, and a signal so you don’t have to say you feel scared out loud. Would that help?
P: Yes. I could go to the reading rug. I like that rug.
D: Great. I’ll write a note for your parents and teacher suggesting a calm-down spot and a plan. Also, talking with a counselor who knows kids can help you practice brave steps, like trying small changes in the classroom slowly.
P: Like going near the new desk one minute at a time?
D: Exactly. Little steps, and you decide the pace. Your parents and teacher will cheer for every try.
P: I like cheering.
D: For now, your tummy and sleep issues sound related to worry. I don’t think we need medicine right away. If things don’t improve in a few weeks or if your tummy gets worse, we can talk about other options.
P: Okay. Will you tell my mom that it’s not silly?
D: I will. Worry is not silly at all. It’s something we can work on together. I’ll give your mom some handouts and we’ll set up a referral to a child counselor. Does that sound okay?
P: Yes. Can Mr. Whiskers come to counseling?
D: Of course—he’s welcome. Anything else you want to tell me?
P: Um...can I get a sticker? I have a sticker collection and it helps me feel brave.
D: Absolutely. I’ve got one right here for brave Harpers who try the five-finger breath.
P: Yay! Thank you, Dr. Lane. Will I be okay?
D: You will be okay. We’ll help you practice ways to feel safer. Your family and your teachers are on your team.
P: Okay. I feel a little less squishy now.
D: Good. Hold Mr. Whiskers when you practice the breathing, and we’ll check in soon. I’ll see you in a few weeks or sooner if you need me.
P: Bye, Dr. Lane. Thank you. Mr. Whiskers says bye too.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Doctor. Um... my name's Emily. I'm eight. I drew you a picture of a dragon but I left it in the car. Sorry.
D: Hi, Emily — nice to meet you. That's okay about the picture. I hear your mom and dad wanted to talk because you've been feeling worried a lot. Can you tell me what's been happening?
P: I get... butterflies. In my tummy. Every morning before school I feel like I ate a whole bunch of butterflies and they won't go away. I told my teacher once and she said maybe I just need to breathe, but it doesn't always work.
D: Those stomach butterflies can be really uncomfortable. Do they happen about anything in particular, like a test, or being away from your mom, or is it different things?
P: Sometimes I worry I'll forget my homework. Sometimes I'm scared the bus will go to the wrong school. And thunderstorms make my heart go thump-thump real loud. My grandma gives me sweet tea and reads me stories so I'm okay after school, but at night I cry 'cause I think about bad stuff.
D: Thank you for telling me. It's brave to talk about the crying and the tummy. Do you ever miss school because of the tummy or cry before you go?
P: I don't miss a lot, but some mornings I say I don't feel good and Mom gets sad. At bedtime I hide under my blanket and think about thunder and monsters at school. Max the dog sleeps by the door so I don't get too scared.
D: I like that Max keeps you company. Worrying about lots of things and feeling sick in your tummy is something we call anxiety. Lots of kids feel it. It sounds like it's been happening for a while and botherin' you at school and bedtime. Does it make it hard to play or draw like you usually do?
P: Sometimes I forget to clean up my crayons 'cause I'm thinking about school. I still play with my brother, but I don't always want to try new things at recess. I don't like surprises no matter how fun they are.
D: Okay. How long has this been going on? A few months? Since you started kindergarten?
P: Since last year it got worse. My teacher says I used to be quieter, but now I cry more. I don't want to be a crybaby though. I try to be brave.
D: You're not a crybaby — you're a kid who's feeling worried. We can figure out ways to help you feel braver. I want to ask a couple quick things: have you had any tummy pain at night that wakes you up, any fevers, or lost weight?
P: No fevers. My tummy doesn't wake me up, it just hurts before the bus. I still eat my dinner — I like Grandma's sweet tea, but she doesn't let me drink it at night.
D: Good to know. Has anything really scary or big happened lately — like a move, a pet getting sick, or someone leaving?
P: No. Well, once our cat hid for two days and I cried lots. I thought she ran away forever. Mom said she was just mad 'cause we wouldn't leave her alone.
D: Thanks, Emily. From what you describe, this sounds like generalized anxiety — lots of worries that make your tummy hurt and make bedtime hard. There are things we can try that help most kids. Would you like to hear some?
P: Yes. Please. I like tips.
D: First, simple belly breathing helps that flutter in your tummy. Put a stuffed animal on your belly, breathe in slow like smelling a cookie for four counts, hold for two, breathe out like you're blowing a feather for five. Do that a few times when the butterflies start.
P: I can do that with my unicorn plushie. I like cookies. Cookie breathing sounds good.
D: Great. Another trick is a "worry box" or book. You write or draw your worry and put it in the box or in a special page — tell yourself you'll check it during "worry time" after school for ten minutes, then close it up until tomorrow. That keeps worries from stealing all your day.
P: I could draw worries. I draw animals and a school with a spaceship playground. Worry time could be after I clean up my crayons... maybe.
D: That sounds perfect. Also, for bedtime we can make a calm-down routine: a warm bath, one story from Grandma, then cookie-breathing, and a little five-minute "good thing" talk where you say three nice things that happened that day. That helps night crying.
P: I like good things. Today I found a ladybug on my bike and Max licked my face. That was good.
D: Those are lovely good things. For the tummy, we'll also check there's nothing else causing it — a quick check and maybe some advice about food. Sometimes sugar or lots of caffeine in sweet tea can make butterflies worse, so keeping sweet drinks earlier in the day helps.
P: I like my tea but I won't drink it at night. Grandma will be okay.
D: Good. Your parents can help by listening when you're worried, naming the feeling — "You seem worried" — and then helping you try a small step, like going to the bus with a plan. It's important they don't promise to fix every worry right away, but help you practice facing small things bit by bit.
P: Like if I worry the bus will go to the wrong school, Mom could walk on the bus day with me?
D: Yes, or she can ask the driver and make a little picture map together so you know what to expect. Predictability helps you feel safe. Also, talking to your teacher about the stomachaches can help — maybe she can let you go to the nurse for a minute when your tummy starts.
P: I feel better knowin' teacher will help. She likes my drawings too.
D: That's great. If the breathing, worry book, and bedtime routine help but you still feel very anxious, the next step is working with a children's therapist who uses cognitive behavioral therapy — they do fun, practice-based things to teach your brain different ways to think about worries. Sometimes kids also benefit from medications, but we only consider that if therapy and strategies aren't enough, and your parents and we would decide that together.
P: Do I have to talk a lot in therapy? I don't like talkin' in front of new people.
D: Therapists who work with kids know that and use games, drawing, and stories — lots of things you already like. You don't have to talk about everything right away. You can start with drawing your worries.
P: Okay. Drawing sounds good. Do I have to do exposure stuff? That sounds scary.
D: Exposure is done slowly and with your permission — like practicing small steps, not big scary jumps. You tell the therapist what's okay and what's too much. The idea is to help you learn you can handle little by little.
P: I can try small steps. Like touching a loud toy first, then a bigger noise. Not too much.
D: Exactly. For now I'll suggest we do a basic check-up for tummy causes, give your parents a plan for home strategies and school notes, and refer you to a children's therapist who knows how to help with anxiety. We'll check back in a few weeks to see how you're doing. Does that sound alright?
P: Yes. Will you tell Grandma I said hi? She makes the best sweet tea.
D: I'll say hi for you. One last thing — if your worries ever make you hurt yourself or you feel like you might, you must tell an adult right away. Do you understand?
P: Yes. I wouldn't do that. I just... worry lots. But I won't hurt myself.
D: I'm glad. You're doing very well talking about this, Emily. Anything else you want to tell me?
P: Um... can I bring my dragon drawing next time? I want you to see him breathing fire but he calms down with cookie breathing.
D: I'd love to see your dragon and how cookie breathing calms him. We'll see you and your parents in a few weeks, and we'll get that referral started.
P: Thank you, Doctor. Bye.
</dialogue>

P: Hi there, Dr. Lee! I'm Emily Watson. It's nice to see you again. *[Emily gives a small wave with her head down slightly]*
D: Hello, Emily! How are you doing today? Why don't you come sit on this examination table and tell me how things have been going?
P: Okay... *I’ve had tummy aches sometimes before school starts, though I know there’s nothing really wrong. Also, my bedtime has felt a little scary recently.*
D: Thanks for sharing that with us today, Emily. Can you describe what happens when your tummy hurts? Are there specific things on your mind then?
P: Well... *[Emily takes a deep breath]* Sometimes, it feels like butterflies in my tummy but bigger—like one of those big balloons after someone's birthday party.
D: I see. And do you have any ideas about why bedtime might be scary or worrisome for you right now?
P: It’s when the dark comes and stuff seems closer, Doctor. Like if there was a monster hiding under my bed, it would be easier to catch them in the light...
D: No monsters here! We can put some nightlights up to help with that if it makes you feel better.
P: *That sounds good.* My parents also read me stories and talk about fun stuff we’ll do tomorrow before lights out. *[Emily gives a shy smile]*
D: That’s wonderful, Emily. Your imagination is so strong—how about talking more about the games you love to play or the art projects?
P: Playing hide-and-seek with my brother helps chase away scary thoughts. And painting animals makes me happy 'cause I can choose which spots go where.
D: It's clear that creativity and activity really help, Emily! We’ll work on finding some strategies and maybe some relaxing exercises to do at bedtime or before you need to be somewhere stressful like school starts.
P: That’d be great. *I think my grandma’s stories help too... when she makes us sweet tea later.*
D: Your grandma sounds lovely, Emily. Sometimes talking about things that worry you with an adult—a parent, a teacher, even your grandmother—can make it feel smaller and more manageable.
P: *[Emily nods slowly, looking thoughtful]* I try to speak up now but sometimes it feels hard...
D: It’s okay if it does feel tough sometimes, Emily. We’ll practice having conversations when you're ready, like talking about your feelings when we play or before an outing with friends. 
P: That sounds easier than talking about monster-under-the-bed stuff at night.*[Emily chuckles softly, feeling a little relieved]*
D: Let's create a plan together that includes the things we talked about today.
P: Can you tell my mom too? *[Emily looks up with her hopeful, sparkling eyes, emphasizing how much she values support and understanding]*
D: I’ll make sure to discuss everything with your parents. They care so deeply about helping you feel more comfortable and confident, just like I do.
P: *I appreciate that! Thanks a lot for wanting to help me, Dr. Lee.*
D: Anytime, Emily. You’re doing great and we'll be there every step of the way.
</dialogue>

D: Hi there, sweetie — I'm Dr. Carter. What's your name?
P: I'm Emily. Hi.
D: Hi Emily. Your mom told me you've been having some tummy aches and getting teary at bedtime. Can you tell me about that?
P: Um. My tummy gets all fluttery like butterflies when Mama's takin' me to school. I feel it in my belly and it won't go away.
D: Does it happen every day or just some mornings?
P: Most mornings. 'Specially on Mondays and when it's a field trip day. I don't like field trips 'cause I'm afraid I won't see Mama.
D: That sounds really hard. Do you ever throw up or have a fever with that tummy ache?
P: No. I usually just hold my belly and sometimes I don't wanna eat breakfast. My teacher said I look pale one time.
D: Do you miss school sometimes because of the tummy aches?
P: Yeah. Mama lets me stay home a few times. I like stayin' home with Grandma 'cause she makes sweet tea and reads me stories.
D: I'm glad you get sweet tea and stories. At bedtime you said you cry — can you tell me what happens then?
P: I get scared when it's dark. Sometimes I think about bad things that might happen tomorrow, like if my class goes somewhere and I can't find my teacher. Then I start cryin' 'cause my heart feels fast and I can't stop thinkin'.
D: Do you have nightmares, or is it more the worry about tomorrow?
P: Mostly worry. But sometimes thunder makes me think a monster's stompin' on the roof and then I wake up.
D: Thunderbugs — yep, they're scary. Do you do anything that helps when you feel that worry?
P: Grandma says deep breaths. I blow like I'm blowin' bubbles. I draw the monsters pretty with polka dots so they don't look so mean. I keep a pink stuffed bunny in my bed, too.
D: I love that you make your monsters pretty — that's smart. You said drawing helps; have you tried telling the worry to a box or putting it in a jar?
P: I did one time. I drew my worry and put it in a shoebox. It felt a little less heavy.
D: That's a great trick. How long have you been feeling this way — a few weeks? Months?
P: Umm. A few months. It sorta got worse when we moved my desk in class and when my brother had his baseball games later.
D: Has anything else been different at home? Any big changes?
P: Nope. We still eat supper and Max the dog still chases his tail. Grandma still comes. I just feel…fussy sometimes.
D: Do you ever feel so sad you don't want to be here anymore, or think about hurting yourself?
P: No, no. I wouldn't wanna leave Mama. I just wanna feel better.
D: Okay, thank you for telling me that. Do you have any tummy pain during the day or no?
P: Not much. Mostly morning. Sometimes if I get a surprise pop quiz I feel it too.
D: How about school — are you able to play with friends and do your work most days?
P: Yeah. I like recess. I play hide-and-seek with my brother and draw animals with my friends. But I worry 'bout the teacher callin' on me sometimes.
D: Thanks, Emily. You said your mom helps you with breathing and Grandma reads stories; those are really good supports. I want to explain something so it's less scary — is that okay?
P: Mm-hmm.
D: Sometimes our brain has a worry-alarm that goes off even when there's no real danger. It makes your tummy hurt and your heart race. It's not your fault, and there are things that can help turn that alarm down.
P: Like the shoebox?
D: Exactly — like the shoebox, and some other tricks too. Would you like me to show you one called "bubble breathing" and another that uses your five senses?
P: Yes. I like bubbles.
D: Alright — bubble breathing is slow: breathe in for four slowly like you're smelling a flower, then blow out for four like you're blowing a big bubble. Want to try with me?
P: Whoa. That made my belly feel a little less jumpy.
D: Nice job. The other one is "5-4-3-2-1": name five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, one thing you can taste. It helps the brain notice right now, not the worry.
P: I can do that. I see your stethoscope. I can touch my dress. I can hear the clock ticking.
D: Perfect. Those tools plus a steady bedtime routine — like a bath, story with Grandma or Mama, and a nightlight for thunder — can help a lot. Would you like a "calm kit" to take to school with a little toy and a drawing?
P: Yes! I could hide my polka-dot monster in it.
D: I love that. I also think working with a therapist who plays games and teaches these tricks could help you get braver with small steps, like staying for a short time at a new activity and building up. How does that sound?
P: Like practice. Like when I learned to ride my pink bike without training wheels. It was scary but then I could do it.
D: Exactly like that. We'll give you small practices and lots of cheerleading. If that doesn't help enough, sometimes we talk about medicine, but only if we need to — many kids do well with the stuff we're talking about and therapy first.
P: Okay. I don't want medicine unless I have to.
