D: That's a good plan. I'll talk with your mom about a referral to a child therapist who knows how to play and help with worries. I'll also give you and your mom a list of things to try at home and at school — like a calm-down corner or a signal with your teacher if you need a minute.
P: My teacher is nice. She might let me go to the quiet table.
D: She probably will. One last thing — sometimes learning to check our thoughts helps. When your brain says "I can't find Mama, something bad will happen," you can ask, "Is that true right now?" and think of a safer thought like "My teacher will help me and Mama will be back at pickup." Want help making a "brave thought" you can say?
P: Hmm. Maybe: "I can be brave for a little bit and Mama comes back." That one.
D: That's perfect, Emily. I'll do a quick tummy and listen to your heart and lungs, okay? That way we make sure there's nothing else going on.
P: Will it hurt?
D: No, not at all. It'll be like a gentle check.
P: Okay.
D: Your belly and heart sound fine. I'm going to give your mom some handouts, refer you to a child therapist for CBT/play therapy, and we'll follow up in a few weeks to see how you're doing. If things get worse or you can't stop crying, call us sooner, okay?
P: Okay. Will you come back to check my shoebox?
D: I can't visit your shoebox, but you can show me your drawings next time — I want to see your polka-dot monsters.
P: Promise. Thank you, Dr. Carter. You're nice.
D: You're very brave, Emily. Keep using your bubble breaths and keep that brave thought. I'll see you and make a plan with your mom.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Harper. Um, I’m here ‘cause my tummy feels funny sometimes before I go to school, and at bedtime, I just start cryin’ and I don’t really know why.
D: Hello, Emily. Thank you for telling me. It’s very brave of you. Can you tell me more about what you’re feeling? Are your tummy pains really bad, or just a little yucky?
P: Well, it’s not so bad, mostly just a weird flutter, like when I’m thinkin’ about a big storm or somethin’ I can’t control. And at night, my eyes just swell up like balloons, and I start bawlin’. It’s like my worries just get real big.
D: That sounds really tough. It’s completely understandable to feel worried sometimes, especially with all that's going on in your mind. Do you maybe think about things that might happen, like thunderstorms or bein’ away from your mom?
P: Uh-huh. I don’t like the dark clouds or when I have to be split up from her on trips at school. It makes my heart beat super fast and I just wanna hide under my covers.
D: Those feelings are very normal, Emily. Feeling nervous or worried is something a lot of kids experience, especially when things seem big or scary. Do you have any special ways you like to calm down when you feel worried?
P: Well… I like to draw pictures. Sometimes I draw my family or my favorite animals. That helps me forget the scary stuff for a while.
D: That’s a wonderful way to help yourself feel better. Drawing can be very soothing. And you’re very good at noticing what helps you. Do your parents tell you stories or make you sweet tea after school?
P: Yes, my grandma does! She reads me stories that make me imagine I’m lost in new worlds, and her tea’s the best, it makes me feel cozy. 
D: That’s lovely, Emily. It’s important to keep doing what makes you feel safe and loved. Would you feel comfortable if we talked about some other ways to help with those worries—like deep breathing or maybe a small routine before bed?
P: I guess I could try… Mom reads me a story and I take some deep breaths, kinda like blowing bubbles in pretend. That might work.
D: That sounds like a perfect idea! I can also suggest a few gentle exercises and some relaxation techniques that you might like. And it might help to talk about your worries with your mom or grandma, so they know how to help you feel better.
P: That would be nice. I wanna feel brave like my favorite superhero, but sometimes I just feel little and scared.
D: You’re already very brave, Emily. And everyone feels little and scared sometimes. The important thing is that you keep talking about your feelings—like you’re doing now. We’ll work together to help you feel more confident and safe.
P: Thanks, Dr. Harper. I like bein’ here ‘cause I can tell you about my worries. It makes me feel a little better already.
D: I’m glad to hear that, sweetheart. Remember, you’re never alone. We’ll make sure you’re supported, every step of the way.

</dialogue>

P : Hi, Doctor. We've been having some issues with Gianna lately. She's been complaining about headaches, and we're worried it's affecting her schoolwork and mood.
D: I see. Can you tell me more about these headaches, Gianna? When did they start?
P : Like, two months ago, I guess. They just come and go, but they're really annoying.
D: Can you describe what they feel like? Do you get any other symptoms, like sensitivity to light or nausea?
P : It's just a really bad headache, like someone's squeezing my brain or something. And yeah, lights and noises are super annoying then too.
D: I see. We'll do some tests to figure out what's going on. Can you tell me more about what's been going on at home and school? Any big changes or stressors?
P : Just school stuff, like homework and annoying teachers. And at home, my little brother's always getting on my nerves.
D: It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of frustration. Have you noticed anything that makes the headaches worse or better?
P : No, they just kinda... come. But, when they're bad, it makes me really short-tempered and my mom and I fight more.
D: Okay, let's talk about some possible treatments. I think we might be dealing with migraines.
P : What's that? I thought only old people got those.
D: No, migraines can affect anyone, even kids. We can try some medication and talk about lifestyle changes that can help you feel better.
P : You mean like, what I eat or something?
D: Yes, that's right. Some foods can trigger migraines, and we can talk about a diet that might help. We'll also look at other factors like sleep and stress management.
P : Okay... maybe that would help.
D: I'll prescribe some medication and give you some more information on lifestyle changes. We'll follow up in a few weeks to see how things are going.
P : Thank you, Doctor. We really appreciate it.
P : I just wanna feel better. I don't like being so... snappy all the time.
D: I know, sweetie. We're going to work together to get you feeling better.
</dialogue>

P: Ugh, can we just start? I don’t even like waiting at home and these chairs aren’t any better.
D: Hi Gianna, I’m Dr. Keller. Sorry to keep you waiting. I hear you’ve been having some pretty bad headaches. Can you tell me what they’re like?
P: They’re terrible. Honestly, it’s like a soccer ball going off in my head but times ten. It just pounds and pounds, especially behind my eyes. Sometimes I can’t even look at the whiteboard at school.
D: That sounds really uncomfortable. How often are you getting these headaches?
P: How much time do you have? Lately, like, three or four times a week. Even during games. My coach says I’ve been losing focus, but he’s wrong by the way. It just hurts too much to play sometimes.
D: Do you notice if anything brings them on? Like certain foods, loud noises, or bright lights?
P: I dunno, maybe when there’s a lot of yelling or too many people around. Or if my little brother is blasting his tablet, which he shouldn’t be doing anyway. And my Nonna insists it’s because I don’t eat enough, like she’s got the answer. But it doesn’t matter if I skip lunch or not. 
D: I see. Do you ever feel sick to your stomach when you get these headaches? Or do you see flashing lights or anything strange before they start?
P: Yeah, once I felt like the room was spinning and I thought I might puke. I had to sit out the rest of the day and everyone looked at me like I was faking. But I don’t see any lights or weird stuff. It just hurts and I get really, really annoyed. Like, I know I snap at people but they should try having a head this loud.
D: That sounds really tough, Gianna. Have you missed any school or sports practices because of your headaches?
P: I hate missing practice, but yeah. My mom made me stay home twice. It was boring, honestly, but my head hurt too much to even go through my soccer cards.
D: What do you do when you get a headache? Do you take any medicine or try lying down?
P: I just want everyone to stop talking and turn off the lights. I’ve tried Tylenol but, I mean, it does nothing. Besides, I hate taking pills. They taste weird even if you hide them in applesauce.
D: Okay, I understand. Has anything else changed recently? Like sleeping, appetite, or how you’re feeling in general?
P: I’m fine, just tired sometimes. My parents say I’m grumpier but, hello, wouldn’t you be? It’s not like I want to yell at everyone. And if someone messes up a group project, that’s not my headache’s fault anyway.
D: That makes sense. We’ll work together to figure this out. I’d like to do a quick exam and then maybe we can talk about some ways to help prevent your headaches. Does that sound okay?
P: Whatever, but let’s make it fast? I’ve got a math test tomorrow and I’m not skipping unless I really have to.
D: Deal. Just one last question—for now. Do migraines run in your family?
P: My mom said she had headaches when she was pregnant with me, if that counts. But nobody else has them like I do. Lucky them.
D: Thank you for telling me all that, Gianna. Let’s get you feeling better so you can get back on the field, okay?
P: You better. I want to win our next game and I can’t do that with my head exploding. Let's go.
</dialogue>

P: Do we have to do this right now? My head’s already buzzing.
D: I’m sorry you’re hurting, Gianna. I’ll keep it quick. Tell me about these headaches.
P: They’re not just headaches. It’s like a jackhammer behind my right eye. Thump-thump. Makes me want to punch a wall. I don’t, okay? I just… want to.
D: How often?
P: Like… two, three times a week. Last two months. Sometimes on game days, sometimes just at school.
D: How long do they last?
P: If I catch it early, a couple hours. If I miss it, it can wreck the afternoon. I have to lie down, no lights, no loud voices.
D: Any warning signs before the pain starts?
P: Yeah, sometimes I get these wiggly lines in the corner of my vision, like heat waves. And I can smell stuff too strong—like the cafeteria pizza smells like a dumpster fire.
D: Nausea? Vomiting?
P: Nausea sometimes. I threw up once after practice. Coach thought I ran too hard. I didn’t.
D: Light and sound sensitivity?
P: Both. The gym whistle is evil. And the classroom lights are like lasers.
D: What helps?
P: If I take Tylenol fast, it helps some. If I wait, it’s useless. Dark room, cold washcloth. Don’t talk to me.
D: Any times it wakes you from sleep?
P: No. I fall asleep, I’m fine. It’s daytime that stinks.
D: Any weakness, numbness, trouble speaking, or balance problems?
P: No. I’m not clumsy. I’m fast.
D: Triggers you’ve noticed?
P: Bright sun at soccer. Not drinking water, I guess. If I skip lunch because the line’s slow—don’t lecture me—boom, headache. Also if I stay up late finishing homework because my group is slow—sorry, they are.
D: How’s your sleep?
P: I go to bed around 10, sometimes 11. Up at 6:45. I know, I know.
D: Any screens before bed?
P: I watch highlights on my phone. It’s relaxing. Until it’s not.
D: Vision checked recently?
P: Last year. I see fine. Just not when the lines start dancing.
D: Any new stressors?
P: Group projects. And my brother keeps drumming on everything. I love the kid, but he’s a human woodpecker.
D: Family history of migraines?
P: Mom gets them. She does that squinty face and tells everyone to whisper.
D: Do you drink caffeine?
P: No. Coffee is gross. Maybe soda on weekends.
D: Have you missed school or practice?
P: I bailed on two practices. And I had to put my head down in math, which was humiliating.
D: Anyone at school understands what’s going on?
P: My teacher tries, but people act like I’m being dramatic. I’m not.
D: I believe you. On exam, your nerves and reflexes look normal. That’s good. This sounds like migraine with occasional aura.
P: So I’m not making it up. Told you.
D: Absolutely real. Here’s a plan: when the wiggly lines or thumping start, take ibuprofen right away with a big glass of water and a small snack. No waiting.
P: How much?
D: Based on your weight, 400 mg. Not more than every 8 hours. Keep it under 15 days a month to avoid rebound headaches.
P: What if it laughs at the ibuprofen?
D: Then we can add a migraine medicine called rizatriptan, a melt tab you take at onset. It’s safe for your age. If the first dose doesn’t work in two hours, you can take a second—max two in 24 hours, and not more than nine days a month.
P: Finally, something with teeth.
D: For nausea, I’ll give ondansetron. Melt tab as needed.
P: Good. I hate puking.
D: Preventing them matters too. Daily targets:
- Sleep: aim for 9–10 hours, same schedule.
- Hydration: water bottle at school and practice.
- Meals: no skipping lunch. Even a yogurt or granola bar.
- Screens: off an hour before bed; use night mode.
- Warm-up and sunglasses/hat for bright practices.
P: I can wear my tinted sports glasses. They look cool anyway.
D: Perfect. Keep a headache diary—when it starts, possible triggers, meds taken, relief. We’ll use it to tweak the plan.
P: Fine. I like stats.
D: If you’re getting four or more bad migraines a month even with this, we’ll talk about daily prevention like magnesium or riboflavin, and only if needed, prescription preventives.
P: I’d rather not take a million pills.
D: Agreed. Also, school note: permission to carry water, brief breaks to a quiet space, and dimmer seating away from bright lights.
P: Please. The front row light is like a spotlight.
D: Red flags: headache that’s the worst ever, different than usual, after a head injury, with fainting, weakness, slurred speech, fever, or waking you from sleep—go to urgent care or ER. Otherwise, message me.
P: Got it. Not panicking, just smart.
D: Any questions?
P: Can I still play this weekend?
D: Yes—hydrate, warm up, sunglasses. If a migraine starts, stop, medicate, and rest.
P: Deal. I’m not quitting, I’m just pausing.
D: Sounds like a champion’s plan. We’ll follow up in four weeks, sooner if needed.
P: Okay. If this works, I’ll admit you were right. Maybe.
D: I’ll take “maybe.” Take care, Gianna.
P: You too, Doc. And tell the nurse her blood pressure cuff squeeze is intense. Not a complaint. Just facts.
</dialogue>

P: I hate coming here. Can we just go back now?
D: Sorry you feel that way, Gianna. We're going to talk about those headaches today, though. How do they make you feel?
P: Like everyone's moving in slow motion and the grown-ups won't leave me alone.
D: That sounds tough. Does the light bother you when your head hurts a lot?
P: Yeah, it’s like I'm looking through a really bright snow globe. But everyone thinks just because it hurts, that means I’m not strong or good enough.
D: Believe me, Gianna, these headaches aren't about being strong. They're more about how your brain is working in a way that causes pain sometimes. Do you feel dizzy too?
P: Sometimes, but my legs feel wobbly like jelly beans and I just want to go to sleep.
D: It's important to rest when you need it, especially if light bothers you or if you're dizzy. Have your parents noticed anything specific that could trigger these headaches? Like certain foods or not enough sleep?
P: Mom says it’s because of too much screen time but it happens whether I watch TV or read comic books.
D: That’s helpful to know. We'll look into how we can manage those triggers better, okay? Do you think talking about them here makes your head hurt even more?
P: Not really—just annoying for both of us if she keeps asking the same thing.
D: I understand it might feel repetitive, but these questions help me figure out what’s going on with your headaches. You’ve been through a lot already by coming here today — thank you.
P: Fine. Can we just check and make sure there's not something major wrong or whatever?
D: We’ll do our best to ensure everything is checked thoroughly. Sometimes simple things can cause big problems, like dehydration or skipping meals. Have you been eating regularly?
P: Yeah, but I prefer soccer balls over salad mostly.
D: That makes sense! Do you find your headaches are worse during certain times of the day, after school perhaps?
P: They get really bad when dad’s coaching and I’m supposed to help my brother with his homework. It’s like there's a drill in my head trying to break through.
D: I understand how that can be so frustrating. Let’s plan something that helps you manage those moments better, okay? We might also look into some gentle exercises that could ease your headaches when they come, maybe?
P: Okay...but what if it doesn't work and nothing fixes it?
D: Well, we won’t give up until we find something that does. You’re strong, Gianna, and you're not alone in this.
P: Fine. Just don't tell me to relax or anything. That's the worst advice ever!
D: I promise, no relaxing talk today! We'll focus on solutions that actually help, okay?
P: Whatever, doc. Let’s get this over with so we can go home.
</dialogue>

P: Hi. I’m Avery. I’d like to explain it myself, please. Also, it’s my abdomen, not just a “tummy.”
D: Absolutely, Avery. I’m Dr. Patel. Is it okay if I mostly talk with you and check in with Mom as needed?
P: Yes. That’s efficient.
D: What’s been going on with your abdomen?
P: For months I’ve had crampy pain, mostly after lunch and sometimes on days with group projects. The pain is around my belly button and left side. It comes in waves. Not a stabbing thing, more like squeezing.
D: How often?
P: Four or five days a week. Some days it’s just annoying, some days I want to curl up like a pill bug.
D: How long does each episode last?
P: Thirty minutes to a few hours. It usually eases after I use the bathroom or if I lay with a heating pad.
D: Any nausea, vomiting, or fevers?
P: Nausea sometimes. No vomiting. No fevers. I’m not faking.
D: I believe you. Bowel movements—how many per day, and what are they like?
P: Usually one in the morning. On the Bristol chart, I’d say Type 5–6 on many days. Sometimes I swing to a Type 2 for a day or two. That’s alternating, which is a thing in IBS.
D: Any blood or black stools?
P: No blood. No tarry stools. Sometimes mucus, which is gross but not surprising.
D: Do the pains wake you from sleep?
P: No. If I’m asleep, I stay asleep. Unlike dolphins, I don’t keep one brain hemisphere awake.
D: Good to know. Appetite and weight?
P: Appetite is fine except when it hurts. My clothes fit the same. Mom says I’m tracking on my growth chart.
D: Triggers you’ve noticed?
P: Milk and ice cream are suspicious. Cheese is less bad. Spicy chips are a clear mistake. Onions can be a disaster. Stressy group work is like flipping a switch. Soccer days are usually okay. Also, soda makes me burpy, which is predictable carbon dioxide.
D: Any other medical issues, allergies, or meds?
P: No allergies. I tried peppermint tea; it helps a little. I’ve taken Tums once. Mostly heating pad and curling up like a fox tail around my belly.
D: Have you started your periods yet?
P: No.
D: Family history of celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, or similar?
P: Mom says no to celiac or IBD. We have general lactose “issues” on her side.
D: How is school with this?
P: Sometimes I’m late back from the bathroom. People make comments. I’d like a bathroom pass without being interrogated. Also, tests plus pain is not ideal. Like monarch butterflies flying 3,000 miles, I can power through, but it’s not efficient.
D: I can write a note for flexible bathroom access and accommodations during tests.
P: That would reduce social friction.
D: I’m going to gently press on your abdomen now—okay?
P: Go ahead.
D: I feel a soft belly, mild tenderness around the belly button, no guarding, no masses. That’s reassuring.
P: Good. Data that matches the hypothesis.
D: From your story and exam, this fits irritable bowel syndrome—what we call a disorder of gut–brain interaction. The gut is healthy, but the nerves and muscles are extra sensitive and reactive to food and stress signals.
P: So it’s not “all in my head,” it’s “in my head and my gut talking loudly.”
D: Exactly. It’s real and painful, but not dangerous or damaging. We can build a plan to reduce flares.
P: I want specifics. Not vague “try to relax.”
D: Fair. Here’s a clear plan. First, nutrition: let’s do a two-week lactose-light trial—lactose-free milk or an enzyme tablet with dairy, and skip ice cream for now or use lactose-free versions. Also reduce common fermenters for a few weeks: big servings of onions/garlic, beans, apples/pears, and fizzy drinks. We can reintroduce later.
P: That’s like a mini–low FODMAP, right? I read about it. Full versions seem extreme for kids.
D: Correct—just a simplified version, and we can involve a pediatric dietitian so you still get balanced nutrition.
P: Okay. I can cooperate with science.
D: Second, fiber: a small daily dose of soluble fiber like psyllium can steady things. Start low—about half a teaspoon in water once daily for a week, then adjust if needed.
P: Soluble, not insoluble. Got it.
D: Third, a probiotic trial for four weeks—something with Bifidobacterium or Lactobacillus. If you don’t notice benefit by then, we stop.
P: I’ll label it like a controlled experiment.
D: Fourth, peppermint oil capsules with an enteric coating before meals can help cramping. Use a pediatric product and follow the label. If it causes heartburn, we adjust.
P: Peppermint relaxes smooth muscle. That makes physiological sense.
D: Fifth, skills for the gut–brain link: short breathing drills twice a day and before tricky moments at school. For example, breathe in 4, hold 4, out 6–8 for two minutes. We can also refer you to gut-directed relaxation or cognitive-behavioral therapy. It’s like training your vagus nerve to be a good teammate.
P: Dolphins sleep unihemispherically. I can breathing-train bihemispherically. Fine.
D: Sixth, bathroom access. I’ll write a letter for your teacher and the school nurse: unrestricted bathroom, permission to carry water, and a plan for test breaks if pain hits.
P: Please include “no commentary from classmates.” They can’t help, but the note might.
D: I’ll phrase it strongly.
P: What about meds on bad days?
D: For gas, simethicone is safe. For constipation stretches, a short course of polyethylene glycol if needed. For cramping, we can consider an antispasmodic like hyoscyamine as needed—after we see how peppermint and fiber do. We’ll review doses with Mom if we go that route.
P: Acceptable. I prefer minimal meds but maximal effect.
D: To be thorough, I’d also like simple tests: a blood test to screen for celiac and check for anemia or inflammation, and a stool test for inflammation. If those are normal, we keep treating this as IBS.
P: Needles aren’t my favorite, but data beats guessing.
D: Fair. Also, keep a two-week log: food, pain level, stool type, stress level. Nothing fancy—just quick notes. Think of it as your field notebook, like tracking a troop of capuchins.
P: I will make columns. I like columns.
D: Great. Any worries you want to say out loud?
P: I don’t want to be the “weird kid” who needs special bathroom rules. And I don’t want you to think I’m dramatic because I correct people. I just like things to be accurate.
D: I hear you. You’re precise, and that’s a strength. We’ll frame the school note around health and privacy. And your pain is valid.
P: Does IBS go away?
D: Many kids improve a lot over time, especially with routines like these. Flares can still happen, but you’ll have tools.
P: One thing I can do today?
D: Switch to lactose-free milk, start the breathing tonight, and put a peppermint capsule in your lunch routine tomorrow.
P: Okay. And for birthday parties?
D: Bring a lactose-free treat or use an enzyme tablet; go easy on sodas and onions-on-pizza; take a quick breathing break if your belly tenses.
P: Pragmatic. Like a fox caching food for later.
D: We’ll follow up in four to six weeks to review your log and results. If things aren’t improving, I’ll bring in a pediatric GI and a dietitian.
P: Deal. Also, butterflies don’t “sleep” like us; they enter torpor. Just, for your notes.
D: Noted: torpor. Thanks for the correction.
P: Thank you for not calling it a “tummy ache.”
D: Thank you for teaching me today, Avery. I’ll print the plan and the school letter now.
P: Good. I like leaving with instructions, not just vibes.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Doctor. I’ve been having these stomach pains for a while now, and it’s really annoying because they sometimes stop me from focusing in class or even playing with my friends.
D: I’m sorry to hear that, Avery. Can you tell me more about when the pain usually happens? Is it after meals, during the day, or at night?
P: Mostly after I eat, especially if the food is spicy or greasy. Sometimes the pain sneaks up even without those foods, which is weird and frustrating because I try so hard to avoid triggers.
D: That does sound tough. Your mom mentioned you've had this discomfort for several months?
P: Yeah, it’s been going on for about six months. I keep a list of what I eat and how I feel in my notebook. It’s a bit like tracking animal migration patterns—looking for clues but sometimes it’s hard to see the pattern.
D: That’s very impressive, Avery. Keeping a food journal is a great idea. Have you noticed any specific foods that always cause pain?
P: Dairy and fried stuff are bad. Also, soda — bubbles just make my stomach feel worse, like there’s a whole pods of tiny dolphins swimming and bouncing inside, but not in a good way.
D: That’s quite an image. It sounds like you might have irritable bowel syndrome, which fits with your symptoms. We can work on ways to manage it so you don’t feel so uncomfortable.
P: My mom says I might have food sensitivities. Does that mean I have to stop eating all the fun stuff forever? Because that would be… sad. Not as sad as finding out dolphins don’t sleep like I thought, though.
D: It doesn’t mean forever, but sometimes we need to limit certain foods to help your tummy heal. We’ll find alternatives that are just as tasty and won’t cause pain. And we’ll work on a plan that fits your daily life, including school.
P: Okay. I guess if I can still read about dolphins and monarch butterflies without stomach aches, that’s a good trade-off. Also, sometimes I worry my classmates think I’m bossy when I point out facts, but with this pain, I don’t want to be bossy, I just want to be okay.
D: You know, Avery, it’s okay to stand up for what’s right and want to be accurate, but it’s also important to be gentle with others and yourself. Managing stress can help with your stomach, too. How do you usually relax or feel calm?
P: I like reading and telling my brother animal facts, even if he pretends to ignore me sometimes. Also, drawing animals helps. Though, when the pain hits, words and colors sometimes don’t help much.
D: Those are wonderful ways to relax. We can also talk about other strategies, like breathing exercises or gentle activity, that might help during painful times.
P: That sounds good. I just want to figure this out and maybe even use my facts to explain what’s going on with my body someday. Like a scientist, but for my own stomach.
D: I love that—you’ll be a fantastic scientist. For now, let’s review your food journal, make a gentle diet plan, and we’ll check back soon to see how you’re doing. How does that sound?
P: Perfect. I’m ready. Thanks, Doctor. I hope this helps so I can get back to feeling like a normal kid, who also happens to know way too much about animals.
D: You’re very welcome, Avery. We’ll get you feeling better, and there’s no such thing as too much animal knowledge. Keep being curious and kind to yourself.
P: Will do. And maybe next time, I’ll bring a new fact about flamingos. They sleep standing on one leg, did you know? 
D: I did now! Looking forward to it.
</dialogue>

P: Hi. I'm Avery. I have a stomachache a lot. It started a few months ago and it comes and goes, usually before lunch and sometimes at night. It feels like cramping, and sometimes I have to run to the bathroom. I don't throw up. I haven't lost weight. I think it might be food or stress. Also my little brother says it's because I eat too fast, which is false — I chew. Did you know sea cucumbers breathe through their butts? But anyway, can you help me stop the pain?
D: Hi Avery, nice to meet you. Thanks for telling me when the pain happens. You mentioned cramping and needing the bathroom — do you usually have diarrhea, constipation, or both?
P: Both. One day it's watery, other days it's hard to go. It's annoying. I track things in my head like migration routes for butterflies, but my mom suggested a food diary, so we started one. Dairy and pizza sometimes make it worse, and ice cream once made me double over. I like facts: I remember that food sensitivity often shows up like this.
D: That’s a very helpful observation. It does sound consistent with irritable bowel syndrome, which can cause alternating diarrhea and constipation, cramping, and symptom triggers like certain foods or stress. We'll want to rule out other causes first — have you had fevers, blood in stool, bad weight loss, or really bad vomiting?
P: No fever. No blood. No big weight loss. I do get nervous about group projects at school; they make me tense and then my stomach hurts. My mom says stress matters. Also I’m mostly fine on school mornings unless I had dairy the night before.
D: Good to know. We'll check a few things: basic blood tests to screen for anemia and inflammation, and possibly testing for celiac disease and stool tests if needed. But a big part of treatment will be symptom management. Would you like to hear options so you can pick what makes sense?
P: Yes. I like choices. And I want facts. Which foods should I actually avoid? My teacher says to drink more water, but that seems too simple.
D: Fair. For children with IBS, we often try a few things: keep a detailed food-and-symptom diary , try reducing high-FODMAP foods for a few weeks under guidance, limit large amounts of lactose if dairy seems to trigger you, and regular meal patterns. Increasing soluble fiber like oats or psyllium can help if you have constipation, but too much insoluble fiber might worsen cramping. Hydration and regular activity help. We can refer you to a pediatric dietitian to make a balanced plan and avoid unnecessary restrictions.
P: Low-FODMAP—I've heard of that. Is it permanent? I don't want to miss out on foods forever. Also, will probiotics work? My encyclopedia said certain bacteria help digestion.
D: Low-FODMAP is usually a short-term elimination then gradual reintroduction to find specific triggers. It’s not meant to be permanent. Probiotics can help some kids, but the effects vary by strain. A dietitian can recommend a child-appropriate probiotic if we think it's helpful. We'll tailor it so you still get enough nutrients.
P: Good. I don't want to give up sushi. Also, my mom worries about tests. Are they painful?
D: Blood draw can pinch but is quick. Stool tests are just samples. If we need more specialized tests or a gastro referral, they’ll explain those steps. We only do what's necessary. I can order basic labs today and give a plan while we wait.
P: Okay. Will relaxation stuff help? My mom tries a breathing app with me and I think it's weird, but sometimes it actually calms me down.
D: Yes, relaxation and stress management often help with IBS. Techniques like diaphragmatic breathing, mindfulness, and cognitive behavioral therapy have good evidence in kids. If you like facts, think of stress as a noisy signal that confuses your gut's "commander" — quieting it can reduce cramps. I can refer you to a pediatric psychologist or a program that teaches these skills.
P: I can try breathing. I might not like group therapy, but one-on-one is okay. Also, what about school? I need a bathroom pass. I get teased when I leave class.
D: We can provide a note recommending easy bathroom access and flexibility with deadlines if symptoms flare. Addressing the teasing is important—your mom and the school can help create a supportive plan.
P: Good. I want to be understood, not treated like I'm faking it.
D: Absolutely. Your symptoms are real. Plan: I'll order blood tests — CBC, inflammatory markers, and celiac screen — and consider stool testing if symptoms suggest infection. I'll refer you to a pediatric dietitian for a structured low-FODMAP trial and to a pediatric psychologist for coping strategies. Start keeping the food-and-symptom diary precisely: time, foods, portion sizes, pain rating, bowel type. Try small meals, regular fiber , stay hydrated, and try breathing exercises when pain starts. If you develop severe vomiting, blood in stool, high fever, rapid weight loss, or nighttime pain that wakes you often, go to urgent care.
P: Sounds like a plan. I will keep the diary and try breathing. Will you tell my mom exactly what to feed me? She worries I'll become picky.
D: The dietitian will give meal plans that are balanced and practical for a family. I'll also speak with your mom about sensible steps and the school note. Anything else you want to ask?
P: One more: are there pills that make it stop right away? I hate missing recess.
D: There aren’t magic pills that fix IBS instantly. For pain flares, we sometimes use short-term antispasmodics or recommend warm compresses and rest. If constipation is a problem, we might use a stool softener or laxative in the short term. We'll use medications only when needed and age-appropriate.
P: Okay. Thank you. Also, fun fact: octopuses have three hearts. I like that better than pills.
D: Great fact, and a good attitude. We'll get the tests started and set up those referrals. We'll check back in a few weeks to see how the plan is working.
P: Bye. I hope the diary proves my pizza theory.
</dialogue>

P: Hi Doctor, thanks for seeing us today. We're here about Avery's stomach issues. She's been having a lot of abdominal pain lately.
D: Of course, happy to help. Avery, how long have you been feeling this pain, and can you tell me a bit more about it?
P: Um, a few months, I guess. It's kinda like... my tummy gets really sore, and sometimes I get diarrhea. And other times I don't go to the bathroom for days.
D: I see. Can you tell me what makes you feel better or worse when this happens?
P: Sometimes my mom gives me ginger tea, and it makes me feel a bit better. But when I eat too much sugar or we have tacos, it gets worse.
D: Tacos, huh? Any idea what it might be about the tacos that bothers you?
P: Maybe the cheese or the beans? My encyclopedias say that some animals get sick from beans. But my friend Emma eats tacos all the time and she's fine.
D: That's an... interesting connection, Avery. But everyone's body is different, so just because Emma is fine doesn't mean you will be. Your mom told me you've been under a bit of stress at school lately? 
P: Just a little. I like learning stuff, but sometimes the other kids tease me, and my teachers get mad at me when I correct them.
D: I understand. Stress can definitely make stomach issues worse. I'd like to run some tests to see if we can find out more about what's going on. But in the meantime, let's talk about some dietary changes we can make. Have you kept a food diary?
P: We've tried to, but it's been hard to get Avery to keep track consistently.
P: I was reading about dolphins the other day. Did you know that dolphins have three stomachs? Maybe I have a stomach like a dolphin and it's getting confused.
D: Avery, that's a creative idea, but I don't think it works exactly that way in humans. As I was saying, a food diary would really help us pinpoint the issue. I can give you a more detailed one to try.
P: That would be great, thank you.
D: Okay, then. After we run the tests, I'd also like to talk to you both about managing stress and finding ways to help Avery cope with it better.
P: Can I still have my animal encyclopedias? They help me relax.
D: Absolutely, Avery. No one's taking away your encyclopedias. We just want you to feel better, okay?
P: Okay... thanks, Doctor.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Patel. Um, I brought my sketchbook, in case we have to wait. I drew a cooper’s hawk. Also, my chest has been squeaky on bike rides.
D: Hi, Emilia. I’d love to see the hawk later. Tell me about the squeaky feeling—when does it start and how long does it last?
P: Usually after like ten minutes of biking or if the trail gets hilly. My lungs feel tight, and I wheeze—like a tiny accordion. It gets better if I stop, but sometimes it hangs around for a while.
D: Any coughing, especially at night or when you wake up?
P: Sometimes at night. Not all the time, but twice last week I coughed before sleeping. It’s worse if my little brother kicks up dust during our epic pillow forts.
D: How often have you used your inhaler in the past two weeks?
P: Maybe… five times? Two on the same weekend because we went hiking and I really wanted to keep up. I used the blue one. I forgot it once and panicked, which made the breathing worse.
D: That sounds scary. Any emergency visits or needing steroid medicine recently?
P: No ER, no big medicines. Just the blue inhaler. I have a spacer. It’s purple and looks like a tiny spaceship.
D: Great that you use the spacer. Do you take a daily controller inhaler—the one with the steroid—every day?
P: I have the orange one. I’m supposed to do two puffs in the morning, but sometimes I forget on weekends. I’m better on school days because I like routines.
D: Thanks for being honest. Skipping doses can make exercise symptoms pop up. Any known triggers—cold air, pollen, pets, smoke?
P: We don’t smoke. We have a cat named Mochi who ignores me unless I open tuna. Grass pollen makes my nose itchy in spring. Cold air on my face also makes me wheezy, like when monarchs hit headwinds.
D: Noted. Any big changes or worries lately?
P: We’re visiting my grandma overseas this summer, and I’m excited but also knot-in-stomach worried. When I worry, I read about pangolins until I forget to breathe slowly.
D: Thanks for sharing. Anxiety can tighten breathing too. We’ll make a plan for both. Before exercise, have you ever tried two puffs of the blue inhaler 15 minutes before starting?
P: Only once, before soccer, and it helped a lot. I could run longer and I didn’t sound like a squeaky toy.
D: Good sign. Here’s what I propose: take your orange inhaler every morning, every day. Let’s also add it at night for the next 6–8 weeks to calm airway inflammation. Use two puffs of the blue inhaler 15 minutes before biking or hiking. How does that feel?
P: I can do that. Can we put it on a checklist? I like checking boxes. It’s like finishing a quest.
D: Absolutely. I’ll print an asthma action plan with green, yellow, and red zones and a checklist. We’ll include reminders. Would you like to review inhaler technique now?
P: Yes. I want to 100% it, like a video game. Sometimes I’m not sure if the puff actually goes in.
D: Okay—shake, exhale, tight seal on the spacer, press once, slow deep breath, hold for 10 seconds, then one more puff after 30 seconds. Rinse and spit after the orange inhaler. Can you show me?
P: [mimes steps] Shake, puff, sloooow inhale, hold… ten, and swish after the orange. Did I pass?
D: Perfect form. About school—does the nurse have an inhaler for you, and do you have permission to use it before recess?
P: I have one in my backpack, but I think the nurse needs new papers. My stepdad loves forms.
D: I’ll send updated forms and the action plan. For triggers: try a light scarf in cold air, shower and change after heavy pollen days, and keep Mochi out of your bedroom.
P: Mochi will protest, but I shall negotiate with tuna.
D: Deal. For the worry knots, try “box breathing”: inhale for 4, hold 4, exhale 4, hold 4—repeat four times. Want to practice once?
P: Okay. In… hold… out… hold… Hey, that actually feels like my brain got a soft blanket.
D: Excellent. Any questions about travel?
P: Can we bring inhalers on the plane? And does airplane air make asthma weird?
D: Inhalers can go in your carry-on; keep them with you. Airplane air is dry, so sip water, use pre-exercise puffs if you expect to hustle through airports, and bring a spacer. I’ll give you a travel letter just in case.
P: Cool. Also, if pangolins curl into a ball to protect themselves, what’s my curl-up plan if I start wheezing on a hike?
D: Your plan: stop, sit, two puffs of the blue inhaler, box breathing while you wait 5–10 minutes. If not better, two more puffs. If you’re in the yellow zone often, we adjust meds; if red zone—can’t speak in full sentences, ribs pulling in—call for help.
P: Got it. Yellow is “caution like a goldfinch,” red is “stop like a stop sign.”
D: Exactly. Let’s check back in four weeks to see how you’re doing with the twice-daily orange inhaler and pre-exercise blue. Message me sooner if night coughs happen more than twice a week or you need the blue inhaler most days.
P: Thank you. I’m going to draw a goldfinch on my action plan. And I’ll try not to breathe like an accordion anymore.
D: I like that plan. You’re doing great, Emilia. Keep being curious—and breathing easy.
</dialogue>

P: Hi Doctor Lee! It's so nice to see you again.
D: Hello there, Emilia! How have you been? I hope school is going well lately.
P: Oh, it’s great, Doctor! But hiking has felt a bit challenging. Sometimes my chest gets really tight and it feels hard to breathe deeply.
D: That sounds like your asthma might be acting up again. Have you noticed any patterns or triggers?
P: Well… in the park sometimes there are lots of plants, flowers blooming. I don’t know what causes it exactly…
D: It’s important to identify those triggers so we can manage them better. Do you remember when you last used your inhaler during a hike?
P: Um... last week? I think maybe once or twice.
D: Good job using it as needed, Emilia. Let's talk about adjusting your treatment plan to help keep those symptoms at bay.
P: Cool! Can we also discuss my activities after this meeting so I don’t have to worry as much?
D: Of course! We can adjust your schedule if necessary to avoid extreme triggers and maybe introduce a new type of inhaler. What do you think about that idea?
P: That sounds amazing, especially since I love going on adventures with friends!
D: Absolutely! It’s all about finding the right balance so you can enjoy being outdoors without discomfort.
P: And Doctor? Can we talk more about how to keep my asthma under control at home too?
D: Definitely. Let's go over some tips and strategies for managing asthma in day-to-day life, okay?
P: Okay! Thanks, I’m looking forward to feeling better soon!
D: You’re welcome, Emilia. We’ll get you back on track, and don’t forget—always communicate with us if your symptoms change.
P: Will do, Doctor Lee. Thank you so much for everything!
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Lee. I brought my sketchbook. Also... my chest does that squeaky thing when I bike now.
D: Hi, Emilia. I’m glad you came in. Tell me about the squeaky thing—when does it happen?
P: Mostly when I’m going fast or going uphill. It feels tight, like my ribs are hugging too hard. Then I wheeze. It sounds like a tiny harmonica.
D: How often in the last month?
P: Ummm… maybe four or five times each week? Hiking, PE, and sometimes when it’s windy.
D: Any coughing or waking at night?
P: I woke up twice this month coughing. Once after a cold. Once after chasing my little brother and laughing too much.
D: Do you use your rescue inhaler?
P: The blue one? Yeah. Two puffs helps in like five minutes. I used it before PE twice last week and on Sunday’s hike.
D: Any days when it didn’t help?
P: It helps, just sometimes I get scared and it feels longer. Mom says my breaths get fast like a hummingbird.
D: What triggers you notice? Cold air, pollen, smoke, pets?
P: Cold air, definitely. And when the cottonwood fluff is flying. No smoke at home. We have a cat, but she’s chill.
D: Any chest pain, fainting, or lips turning blue?
P: No. Just tight and squeaky. And I get frustrated because I like keeping up.
D: How’s school and PE going?
P: Good! I got a gold star for my monarch butterfly poster. But I sat out of tag last Thursday.
D: Do you have an inhaler at school?
P: In the nurse’s office. And one in Mom’s bag. None in my backpack.
D: Have you ever used a spacer with your inhaler?
P: The tube thing? We lost ours. It made the puff less scary.
D: We’ll get you a new one. Any allergies—itchy eyes, sneezing?
P: My nose gets drippy in spring. I say I have “pollen brain.”
D: Any hospital visits or steroids this year?
P: Nope.
D: I’m going to listen to your lungs. Big breaths like blowing out birthday candles.
P: Okay. Whooo… whooo… like a whale.
D: I hear mild wheeze at the end of your breaths. Oxygen looks good. We’ll do a breathing test today to check lung function. Sound okay?
P: Can I see the graph? I like graphs.
D: Absolutely. We’ll print it for your sketchbook if you want.
P: Yes! I’ll draw it like tree branches. Lungs are kind of like upside-down trees anyway.
D: Great analogy. So, you’re using your rescue inhaler a few times a week and waking at night sometimes. That tells me your asthma needs stronger daily control.
P: Does that mean I can’t hike?
D: You can still hike. The plan is to keep your airways calm so hiking feels easy again.
P: How?
D: We’ll start a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid—one controller puff twice a day with the spacer. It quiets the airway inflammation. You’ll rinse and spit afterward.
P: Is it like… telling my lungs to chill?
D: Exactly. And use your blue inhaler two puffs 15 minutes before exercise. Carry it with you.
P: Can I decorate the spacer? Stickers make it friendlier.
D: Stickers are perfect. Just keep the mouthpiece clear.
P: How long do I have to do the controller puffs?
D: Every day for at least 6–8 weeks. We’ll recheck. If you’re great, we might step down.
P: What if the air gets cold again?
D: Scarf over your mouth and nose to warm the air, and pre-treat with your inhaler.
P: What if it gets bad-bad? Like coyote-bad, not puppy-bad.
D: We’ll make an asthma action plan: green, yellow, red zones. If you’re in yellow—cough, wheeze, using rescue more—you’ll take your rescue inhaler and let your parents know. Red zone—if you’re struggling to speak, ribs sucking in, lips blue—use the rescue and go to urgent care or call 911.
P: Can you write it all down? My brain does cartwheels when I’m nervous.
D: I will. I’ll also send a copy for school and a note so you can carry your inhaler.
P: Thank you. Also, do butterflies get asthma? They have tiny tubes for breathing.
D: Insects have spiracles and tracheae, but no asthma. Humans and our reactive airways are special.
P: Figures. I’m special. In a squeaky way.
D: Special and strong. Any recent colds?
P: Last week. Lots of tissues. That’s when the night cough happened.
D: Viral colds can flare asthma. The controller will help reduce that.
P: Do shots help? Like flu shots?
D: Yes. Flu and COVID vaccines reduce bad flares. You’re due for the flu shot this fall.
P: Okay. I’m brave with shots if I count in Vietnamese.
D: Great strategy. Do you ever feel anxious when breathing gets tight?
P: Yeah. My tummy flips. I forget how to slow down.
D: Let’s practice: in through your nose for four, hold for two, out through pursed lips for six—like blowing through a straw. Try now.
P: In… hold… out… That feels steady.
D: Use that with your inhaler if you feel panicky. It helps the medicine work.
P: Will the controller make me jittery?
D: The controller shouldn’t. The rescue can a little. If anything feels off, tell us.
P: Can I still lead my park walks on Saturday?
D: Yes—with your pre-exercise puffs, inhaler on you, scarf if it’s cold, and breaks as needed.
P: Deal. I’ll make a bug-of-the-day list. And not race the big kids.
D: I’ll send your prescriptions, order the spacer, set up spirometry now, and we’ll follow up in six weeks. Questions?
P: Just one. If my lungs are like trees, can I think of the controller puff as rain?
D: Perfect. Gentle rain for your lung-forest.
P: Then let it rain. I’m ready.
</dialogue>

P: Hi Dr. Lee! Thanks for seeing us today. I’ve been having trouble breathing lately, especially when I go hiking or bike really fast. At first, I thought it was just the air, but it’s been happening more often, and I get this wheezy sound sometimes when I breathe out. 
D: Hello, Emilia. Thanks for sharing that with me. It’s good you told me. When did you first notice these new symptoms? Was it suddenly or gradually? 
P: Well, I think it started about two weeks ago. It was just once or twice during a hike, and I thought maybe I was just out of shape. But then it kept happening, even when I was just running around at recess. 
D: That sounds frustrating. Do you notice if it happens more on certain days or after doing specific activities? 
P: Hmm, I think I breathe a little easier if I rest for a bit, but then it comes back if I keep going. And I think it’s worse if the air is cold or if I’ve been exposed to a lot of dust or pollen. My mom says I might be allergic to something outside. 
D: That’s a good observation, Emilia. Allergies can sometimes make asthma symptoms worse. Do you use your inhaler sometimes during these episodes? 
P: Yes. I have an inhaler, but I don’t always remember to use it. Sometimes I feel okay for a while, and then suddenly I can't catch my breath. It makes me a little nervous. 
D: That’s understandable. It’s important to have your inhaler ready, especially during activities you enjoy. How many times have you needed to use it in the past week? 
P: Maybe three or four times? I tried to tell my parents, but I don’t want to overdo it, so I only use it when I really have to. 
D: It’s good you’re careful. We’ll do a quick check today and see if your treatment plan needs a tweak. Can you tell me what you do when you feel short of breath? 
P: Usually, I sit down and try to breathe slowly. Sometimes I take my inhaler, and that helps after a minute or two. But I don’t like how I feel—like I’m not in control. It makes me worry that it might get worse. 
D: That’s a very mature way to handle it, Emilia. We’ll work together to find some solutions to help you breathe easier and feel more confident when you’re outside. Do you have any questions for me right now? 
P: Yeah! Does this mean I can’t climb trees or go on big hikes anymore? I love exploring! 
D: Not at all! With a proper plan, you can still enjoy all your adventures. We might just add some medicines or tips to keep your breathing steady, especially during active days. 
P: Okay! That sounds better. I really want to be like a brave explorer, not worried about my lungs. 
D: And you are a brave explorer, Emilia. We’ll make sure your asthma doesn’t hold you back. Let’s start by checking your lungs now, shall we? 
P: Yes! Thanks, Dr. Lee. I’m ready!
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Reed. I’m Samantha, and I love science and soccer, especially when I get to try new stuff on the field. I’ve been coughing a lot at night and I notice I get winded on the field more than usual.
D: Nice to meet you, Samantha. I’m glad you told me. Quick check: you’ve been using your inhaler when you feel short of breath, right?
P: Sometimes, yes. I forget to bring it to practice, and I don’t always use it fast enough. My mom tells me I should, but I bite my lip and keep going.
D: That’s common, but we want to keep you playing safely. Tell me more about the cough at night. Is it wet or dry? Any chest tightness?
P: It’s a dry cough, and it kind of squeezes my chest a bit. It keeps me from falling asleep sometimes, especially after practice.
D: I see. It sounds like your asthma could be waking you at night. How long has this been going on?
P: A few weeks, maybe since we started practicing more with the team. I still love practice, though. The team is super supportive.
D: That’s great to hear about the teamwork. Do you notice your symptoms after you run sprints, or does it happen during warm-ups too?
P: Mostly after the sprints. I’ll jog and feel winded, then my chest feels tight and I start coughing a lot.
D: Okay. We should review your current asthma plan and maybe adjust meds or strategies. Do you use a rescue inhaler before activities?
P: Sometimes. I forget to do it before I start, and then I’m already wheezing.
D: We can set a routine. Also, do you have any triggers like dust, pollen, or cold air that you’ve noticed?
P: Cold air bothers me during night practice when the gym door is open. And sometimes dust from the gym mat stuff.
D: Noted. We’ll tailor your plan to keep you playing safely. What about nighttime routines—any other symptoms?
P: Just the coughing and a couple of times I woke up short of breath. But I still fall asleep after I rest a bit.
D: Alright. I’d like to check your lungs with a quick listen and maybe do a simple test to see how your airways respond. Then we’ll decide if we need to adjust your inhaler dosage or add a spacer.
P: I’m a bit nervous about the test, but I’m also curious how my lungs look. I’m the kid who asks a lot of questions.
D: That curiosity will help. I’ll explain everything as we go. Do you still bake with your mom and enjoy science experiments at home?
P: Yes! Baking is my favorite way to unwind after practice, and I love tiny science projects—bubbles, reactions, you name it.
D: Wonderful. Some kids with asthma do well with a finetuned routine around exercise and a spacer for meds. We’ll consider all of that. How about school days—any symptoms during class or after PE?
P: Sometimes after gym I get breathless, but I can usually catch my breath with a quick rest. I don’t want to miss Science Day anymore because of this.
D: We’ll plan ahead for science day and gym days. If needed, we can add a daily controller inhaler or adjust timing around activities. You’re doing great by speaking up.
P: I want to keep asking questions and figure this out. I don’t want my asthma to steal my goals.
D: I admire that. We’ll create a clear, practical plan you can follow at practice, at home, and at night. Let’s start with the lung check and then we’ll map out a personalized action plan.
P: Okay. And if I need help, should I bring my mom to every practice to remind me?
D: It’s fine to have support at the start, but we’ll build independence so you can manage confidently. Your parents will be part of the plan, especially at first.
P: I’m ready. Let’s do this—I want to keep chasing every goal with curiosity and a big, brave breath.
D: Excellent. We’ll work together to keep you active, safe, and breathing easy.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Patel. Um... I’m okay, just kinda wheezy lately.
D: Hi, Samantha. I’m glad you’re here. Tell me what’s been going on.
P: So at soccer I get short of breath way faster than usual. Like I barely get through warm-ups and it feels like I’m sucking air through a skinny straw.
D: How many practices or games has that happened in the last two weeks?
P: Three practices and our game on Saturday. I had to sub out twice, which I hate.
D: I hear you. Any coughing or wheezing at night?
P: Yes. I woke up coughing three nights this week. It’s squeaky sometimes. My mom heard me from the hallway.
D: Have you been using your rescue inhaler when that happens?
P: The blue one, yeah. Two puffs. It helps but then I’m kinda jittery for a bit.
D: How often in a week are you using it now?
P: Uh… maybe four or five times? More on soccer days.
D: Do you take it before practice, about 15 minutes early?
P: Sometimes I forget. I keep it in my bag next to my shin guards, but I get excited and run out.
D: Makes sense. Do you use a spacer with it?
P: Yep, the clear tube thing. I shake-shake, press once, then breathe in slow and hold like ten seconds. I practiced in the mirror.
D: Excellent technique. Any colds or allergies lately? Stuffy nose, itchy eyes, sneezing?
P: Our field grass was just cut and my nose goes “itch-attack.” Also my neighbor’s cat rubs on my legs. I love him, but then I sniffle.
D: Sounds like allergies might be poking your airways. Any smoke exposure at home or in the car?
P: Nope. My parents are like “no smoky anything.” Even scented candles are banned.
D: Good. How about school—does the coughing bother you in class or during recess?
P: Sometimes I cough in math, which is embarrassing. I try to cough-into-my-sweater so it’s quiet.
D: Have you had to miss school, go to urgent care, or need oral steroids recently?
P: No missing school. No emergency stuff. Just tired from the nighttime coughs.
D: Got it. I’m going to listen to your lungs. Big breaths in and out for me.
P: Okay. Like blowing up a balloon?
D: Exactly. In… and out. Good. I hear a little tightness at the bases, but overall air is moving well.
P: That’s good, right? Because it feels grumpy in there.
D: It’s not dangerous right now, but your asthma isn’t as controlled as we want. The goal is you running full speed and sleeping all night.
P: Yes, please. I want to chase the ball, not my breath.
D: You’re using the blue rescue inhaler correctly. I’d like to add a daily controller—an inhaled steroid you take morning and night. It calms the swelling inside the breathing tubes so they don’t clamp down.
P: Like telling my lungs to chill before they freak out?
D: Exactly. The blue one relaxes the muscles right away; the controller quiets the inflammation so you need the blue one less.
P: Science question—are those the tiny tube branches that look like a tree?
D: Yes. The bronchi are the branches, and the little air sacs at the ends are like clusters of grapes. Right now the branches are puffy and a bit sticky with mucus.
P: Ew but also cool. If I use the controller, do I still take the blue one before soccer?
D: Yes—two puffs 15 minutes before warm-up. And keep doing a gradual warm-up, not a sprint from zero.
P: I can do that. Coach makes us do ladders anyway.
D: After the controller, rinse your mouth and spit so you don’t get a throat yeast infection. If your voice gets hoarse, tell me.
P: Got it—swish and spit like after brushing. Will it make me… like, puffy or mess with growing?
D: At the low dose we’ll use, it’s very safe. We’ll track your growth as always. The bigger risk to growth is poorly controlled asthma.
P: Okay. That makes me feel better.
D: We’ll also give you a written asthma action plan: green zone when you feel good, yellow if you start coughing or wheezing, red if you’re really struggling. It tells you exactly what to do.
P: Can I color-code it and put it in my binder? I like charts.
D: Please do. You can even log symptoms like a science experiment—time of day, what you were doing, and if you used your inhaler.
P: I’ll make a graph! Maybe a scatterplot of coughs.
D: Love it. Do you want to self-carry your inhaler at school? We can fill out the form so you don’t have to go to the nurse every time.
P: Yes, please. Asking in front of kids makes me shy.
D: Done. Any heart racing or chest pain when you use albuterol?
P: Just hand shakies sometimes. It goes away fast.
D: Normal side effect. If it gets bothersome, tell me. Also, try to keep the inhaler out of extreme heat or cold—don’t leave it baking in the car.
P: Oops, soccer bag lives in the garage. I’ll bring it inside.
D: Good plan. For allergies, rinsing your nose with saline after practice can help. If you’re still sneezy, we can add a daily non-drowsy antihistamine.
P: Salty nose shower. I can handle that.
D: If you ever need the rescue inhaler more than twice a week, or you wake up coughing more than twice a month, that’s our signal to adjust sooner.
P: Twice a week, twice a month. I’ll remember.
D: Any questions I didn’t answer?
P: Why is it worse at night? I was fine all summer.
D: Airway muscles can be twitchier at night, and lying down can let post-nasal drip tickle your throat. Fall allergens and cooler air add to it.
P: So my lungs are drama queens after bedtime.
D: A little theatrical. We’ll calm the stage.
P: Can I still play the whole game if I do the plan?
D: That’s the goal. Many athletes have asthma and compete at high levels with good control.
P: Okay. I’m ready to sprint like a cheetah again.
D: Perfect. I’ll send the prescription for a low-dose inhaled steroid, the action plan, and the school form. Start the controller today. Use two puffs of albuterol before soccer and as needed.
P: And rinse my mouth. And warm up. And make a graph.
D: You’ve got it. Let’s follow up in four weeks, sooner if things don’t improve or if you’re worried.
P: Deal. Thanks, Dr. Patel.
D: You’re welcome, Samantha. Go score some goals.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Doctor Lee! It’s great to see you again. I’ve been really busy with my drawing and soccer, but I couldn’t ignore this breathing thing any longer.
D: Hello, Samantha! How are you feeling today? Can you tell me more about your shortness of breath during soccer practice?
P: Sure, Dr. Lee. Well, when we run drills or play games late in the day, my chest gets tight and I feel like it’s hard to breathe deeply. It’s kind of scary because normally I’m full of energy and love running around!
D: That does sound concerning. Have you had any trouble sleeping at night too?
P: Yeah, a bit. Sometimes I wake up coughing or wheezing if the air is chilly in my room.
D: Okay, it sounds like your asthma might be flaring up more than usual. We’ll need to tailor your management plan to help control these symptoms better. Can you tell me about any changes at home or school recently?
P: Um... Well, I started a new diet program with my parents because there are lots of sugary snacks in our house. They’re trying to make us healthier.
D: That’s great progress on your family’s health journey! Sometimes it can take some adjusting for our bodies when we change habits like that.
P: Oh yeah, and the weather has been pretty cold lately too.
D: I see. Well, these changes in diet and temperature could be factors. Let's review what you've been using now for asthma management.
P: Okay! We usually use my blue inhaler before soccer practice but it hasn’t worked as well over the last few weeks.
D: Alright, we might need to consider a change then. We can switch you to a different inhaler that works for shorter-term bursts of relief and start a maintenance treatment at night.
P: Is this going to make me slow down on my activities?
D: Not at all! It’s designed to help you feel more comfortable and keep up with your adventures. Just like adjusting your soccer strategy when playing against tough teams, we’re making adjustments for better performance in everything you do.
P: That sounds good to me! Can I ask about any tips to avoid my symptoms?
D: Absolutely—taking preventive steps is crucial. Staying hydrated, knowing your triggers, and keeping warm during sports activities will all help a lot!
P: Wow, it’s really nice to know there are ways to deal with this so that I can stay active like always.
D: Of course! And let's make sure you visit us here anytime if things get worse. We're your team, okay?
P: Thanks, Dr. Lee! You’re the best!
D: Anytime, Samantha. Enjoy making those drawings and keep on kicking goals in soccer too!
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Martin! Thanks for seeing us today. I’ve been having a little more trouble catching my breath when I’m running really fast during soccer, and I’ve also been coughing a lot at night, especially when I lie down. 
D: Hello, Samantha. Thanks for sharing that with me. It’s good you came in so we can figure out what’s going on. Have you noticed if your breathing problems happen during specific times or activities?
P: Well, it mostly happens during soccer practice, especially when I’m chasing the ball or sprinting. I think I breathe okay when I’m just walking around or playing in the yard, though. And the cough wakes me up sometimes, but I don’t always feel sick otherwise.
D: That sounds like it’s been a bit more than usual. Have you been using your inhaler the way you’re supposed to? Or maybe more often?
P: I’ve used it a couple of times, but not every day. Sometimes I forget, or I don’t think I need it if I’m not feeling super wheezy. 
D: It's common to forget, but it's important to use your inhaler as prescribed, especially when you’re active. Do you know if you’ve had any other symptoms around that time, like feeling tight in your chest or coughing during the day?
P: I do feel a little tight sometimes, especially after playing. And my mom says I sound wheezy when I breathe in. 
D: That’s helpful to know. It sounds like your asthma might be a little more active now. We can look at your current plan and see if we need to make some adjustments to help you breathe easier during soccer and at night. How does that sound?
P: That sounds good! I really want to keep playing soccer — it’s super fun. I don’t like feeling all tired and stuff after running a lot. 
D: Absolutely! We want you to enjoy playing without worrying about your breathing. I’ll suggest some changes to your medication and give you tips on managing your asthma during games and bedtime. And we’ll set up a follow-up to see how you’re doing. Do you have any questions for me now?
P: Um, yeah. Will I need to use my inhaler more often? Or will I have to take other medicines? I want to make sure I can still play and everything.
D: Good questions, Samantha. We’ll likely adjust your inhaler so it gives you enough relief when you need it, especially during activity. We might also think about adding or changing some of your medication, but I’ll discuss all of that with your parents. The goal is to keep you safe and active. Anything else you’re curious about?
P: No, I think that’s it. Thanks for listening, Dr. Martin. I really want to get back to running around and scoring goals without coughing so much! 
D: You're very welcome, Samantha. You’re doing a great job talking about how you feel. We’ll work together to help you breathe easy so you can keep having fun on the soccer field.
</dialogue>

P: Hola, doctor. Gracias por recibirme hoy. La verdad, me siento un poco cansada, y en la escuela me cuesta concentrarme. A veces, siento que todo me da vueltas y me falta energía para jugar con mis amigos. 
D: Hola, Mariana. Gracias a ti por venir. Entiendo que te sientes muy cansada últimamente y que te cuesta concentrarte en clase. ¿Has notado algo más, como mareos o que te duele algo en particular? 
P: Pues, sí, me he sentido algo mareada cuando me levanto rápido, y mi mamá dice que estoy más pálida que antes. Pero no me duele nada, solo esa sensación de que no tengo mucha fuerza. 
D: Es importante que hayamos detectado estos síntomas, Mariana. Tu mamá y yo estamos preocupados porque esto puede ser por una anemia por deficiencia de hierro. Es bastante común y podemos tratarlo con cambios en la alimentación y, si es necesario, suplementos. 
P: ¿Y eso qué significa exactamente, doctor? ¿Voy a estar bien? Solo quiero volver a sentirme fuerte otra vez para jugar y dibujar en clase, como siempre. 
D: Claro, Mariana. Eso generalmente se puede mejorar mucho con la ayuda adecuada. Vamos a hacer unos análisis de sangre para confirmar. Mientras tanto, te recomiendo comer más alimentos ricos en hierro, como espinacas, carne y frijoles, y también asegurarte de tener una dieta balanceada. 
P: ¡Me encanta aprender recetas nuevas con mi mamá! Espero que esas cosas me ayuden. ¿Y cuánto tiempo tardaremos en saber si todo está bien? 
D: Normalmente, en unos días tendremos los resultados y te explicaré todo con calma. No te preocupes demasiado; con el cuidado correcto, pronto te sentirás mucho mejor para seguir jugando y disfrutando tus actividades favoritas. 
P: Muchas gracias, doctor. Espero que solo sea eso y que nada más esté mal. Quiero volver a sentirme fuerte y feliz como antes. 
D: Eso haremos, Mariana. Gracias por ser tan valiente y por cuidarte. Nos aseguraremos de que recibas toda la ayuda que necesitas para que puedas seguir haciendo lo que más te gusta.
</dialogue>

P: ¡Buenos días! Soy Mariana, estoy aquí por un examen porque me siento más cansada que nunca.
D: Buenos días, Mariana. Encantado de conocerte. Cuéntame, ¿desde cuándo te sientes así?
P: Empecé a sentirme un poco rara hace como tres semanas, pero a mitad del mes pasado empecé a dormir mucho y no me quito el cansancio.
D: Eso suena bastante incómodo. También has mencionado que tienes dolor de cabeza frecuente o te sientes mareada?
P: Sí, definitivamente noto que cuando corro en el parque no tengo la misma energía de siempre y a veces hasta me aturullo un poco.
D: Entiendo por lo que estás pasando. Veamos si algunos exámenes pueden dar luces sobre esto. 
P: Ahora mismo estoy apunto de tener una prueba importante, quiero quedarme en buen estado.
D: Lo sé, Mariana, entiendo tu preocupación. Vamos a hacerte un análisis de sangre para averiguar qué está sucediendo con tu energía.
P: ¿Y eso me ayudará a sentirme mejor?
D: Eso espero. Seguro que vamos a encontrar la razón detrás de este cansancio y haremos algo al respecto. 


</dialogue>

P: Hi… um, thank you for seeing me today. My mom said you might want to know how I’ve been feeling? I guess I’ve just been super tired lately. Even when I actually get to sleep in, which almost never happens, I still feel like a zombie.
D: Of course, Mariana. I’m glad you could come in. How long have you been feeling this tired? Has anything changed recently at school or at home?
P: Umm, I think it started a few weeks ago? At first it was just, like, feeling lazy after soccer or after babysitting, but now it’s more all the time. I even fell asleep while watching a movie with my little cousin, and she totally drew on my arm with markers. My mom says I look pale too, but I didn’t really notice.
D: That’s helpful to know. Besides being tired, have you felt dizzy at all, or short of breath when you’re playing soccer or doing other activities?
P: Yeah, actually. The other day at the park, I stood up too fast and everything spun around for a second. And when I try to run, I get out of breath way faster than before. It makes it hard to keep up with everyone. They probably think I just need more practice, but… I don’t know.
D: Have you noticed any changes in your appetite, or do you have cravings for unusual things—like ice or clay, sometimes people mention that?
P: Um… Not really clay or anything, but I do chew on ice a lot at home. My abuelita says that’s not good for my teeth, but I like how it feels. I haven’t really wanted to eat much meat lately either. Most days, it’s just frijoles and rice or soup.
D: Thank you for sharing that. I’m going to listen to your heart and check your breathing and then we’ll talk about some blood tests. Has anyone in your family ever had problems with anemia or issues with iron?
P: Hmm, I’m not totally sure. My mom sometimes says she gets really tired if she doesn’t eat enough carne, but I don’t think anyone’s talked about, like, real anemia. Sorry, I should ask more.
D: No problem, Mariana. You’re giving me plenty of good information. How about school—how is your concentration? Any headaches or problems focusing in class?
P: It’s kinda hard to focus, honestly. Especially when the teacher is talking, I feel like the words just… float around. I got a not-so-great grade on my math test, which never happens, and I keep making silly mistakes on my assignments. I’ve had a couple of headaches too, but I thought it was just because I needed glasses or something.
D: You’re doing a great job explaining how you feel. I think checking your iron levels will be important. Is it okay if we do a quick blood test today? It only takes a moment, and I’ll talk you and your mom through it.
P: Si, está bien. I mean, yes, that’s fine. I get nervous with needles, but I can do it. My little brother would make a big fuss, but I’m braver than him, I think. 
D: I believe you. We’ll make it as quick and easy as possible. After the test, I’ll let you know what we find, and we can talk about helping you feel more like yourself again. Your mom and I can discuss some ideas for meals, too.
P: Thank you, doctor. Um… is there anything I should do right now? Like, no soccer or anything? Or can I go to my art club after school?
D: You can still do your activities, but just listen to your body—if you feel too tired, it’s okay to rest. We’ll know more once we get your results back. And don’t worry, Mariana. We’ll help you get back to your soccer games and your art—maybe you can even draw me something next time you’re here.
P: Sure, I can do that. Maybe something with less math problems, though. Thanks for listening. It helps just to talk about it.
</dialogue>

P: Hola, doctor. Bueno, I’ve been feeling super tired lately, even when I’ve slept a lot. Like, I still wanna nap all the time, you know? It’s kind of weird because I usually have más energía, especialmente after soccer with my friends. 
D: I understand, Mariana. You're feeling unusually tired and a bit dizzy, it sounds. Have you noticed anything else? Maybe any pain or changes in your mood?
P: Yeah, actually. I get dizzy sometimes, especially when I stand up fast. And my skin looks kinda pale, I think. My mamá says I look "menos rosada" than before. I also find it hard to focus at school, which is frustrating because I love drawing and working on projects.
D: Those are important observations. It can all be connected. Given your symptoms and your mom's concerns, we should do some blood tests to see what's going on. Has anyone in your family had something similar or known health issues?
P: Hmm... Maybe my older sister once felt tired all the time, but she was just stressed with her exams. My mamá thinks I might need more iron because I don’t eat enough meat sometimes, and I like more beans and rice. But I’m not sure; I just wanna feel better so I can keep doing todos mis cosas sin estar cansada.
D: That’s very insightful of you, Mariana. Your diet can definitely influence your energy levels. The blood work will help us figure out if you have anemia, which is common and can cause fatigue and paleness but is easily treatable. Do you have any questions for me?
P: Um, yeah. Is it okay if I’m nervous? I don’t like needles very much, and I worry about the blood test. Will it hurt mucho?
D: It’s normal to be nervous, Mariana. The blood draw is quick, and we’ll do everything to make you comfortable. You might feel a tiny pinch, but it will be over before you know it. Would you like to listen to music or have a squeeze toy during the procedure?
P: Oh, I’d love to have some music! Maybe I can listen to my favorite playlist. Also, can I bring my doodles and color while I wait? That helps me calm down normally.
D: Absolutely, bringing your favorite things sounds like a great idea. I’ll make sure the nurse knows. After we get the test results, we’ll discuss what steps to take to help you feel better and have más energía para todo—school, soccer, and spending time with your familia.
P: Gracias, doctor. Thanks for helping me figure this out. I just wanna get back to feeling más fuerte and being able to do everything I love again.
</dialogue>

P: Hi, Dr. Lee. Thanks for seeing me today.
D: Of course, Emily. What seems to be the problem? Your mom mentioned something about allergies?
P: Yeah... Every year I get allergies in the spring, but this time it's really bad. I'm always sneezing and my eyes are super itchy. I feel like it's getting worse.
D: That does sound uncomfortable. Can you tell me more about when your symptoms started this year? Was it around the same time as usual?
P: Um, yeah... I think so. It usually starts when all the flowers and trees bloom. I love that time of year, but... I guess my allergies don't.
D: That's understandable. And I see you babysit quite a bit. Do you think being around kids outdoors might be making your symptoms worse?
P: Yeah, definitely. Sometimes we play outside, and I'll start sneezing a lot. The kids get worried about me, and it's hard to take care of them when I'm feeling like that.
D: That must be challenging. Have you tried any over-the-counter medications or remedies to help manage your symptoms?
P: We've tried some stuff, like Benadryl and eye drops. But my mom's worried that I might need something stronger this time. That's why we came to see you.
D: Okay. Well, let's take a look at your symptoms and see if we can come up with a better plan. I see you're pretty active, with soccer and all. Do you find that exercise makes your symptoms better or worse?
P: Actually... I think it helps a bit. When I'm running around on the soccer field, I don't notice my allergies as much. But after the game, when I'm sitting still, it hits me again.
D: That's interesting. Exercise can sometimes help alleviate allergy symptoms. I think we might need to consider a prescription medication to help you manage your symptoms, especially on days when you're outdoors. I'll also recommend some additional steps you can take to minimize your exposure to allergens.
P: Okay, that sounds great. Thanks, Dr. Lee. I just want to be able to take care of the kids without sneezing all over them. 
D: I think we can work towards that. I'll write you a prescription and give you some instructions on how to use it. Let's also schedule a follow-up appointment in a few weeks to see how things are going, okay?
P: Sounds good. Thanks again, Dr. Lee.
D: You're welcome, Emily. Take care, and feel better soon.
</dialogue>

P: Hi Dr. Johnson, it’s Emily Harrison. I’m really glad to see you today.
D: Hello, Emily! How are you doing? It sounds like things have been a bit rough with your allergies lately. Can you tell me more about what you’ve been experiencing?
P: Sure, um, well, my nose has just been so runny for weeks now. I sneeze a lot, especially in the morning and early evening when it’s still kind of light out. My eyes are itchy too, but they’re usually okay if I wear sunglasses.
D: That sounds tough. When did you first notice things getting worse?
P: It started around March, which was right after basketball season ended. We hadn’t really thought much about allergies until this spring. Now that I’m outside more for soccer practice and babysitting little kids, it definitely doesn’t help.
D: Right, the flowers are blooming everywhere now. Have you taken any over-the-counter meds?
P: Yeah, my parents got me some allergy tablets a couple of weeks ago. They did make things better at first, but they stopped working pretty quickly after that.
D: I see. It sounds like your symptoms might be more severe now than before. Have the other kids around you been having similar issues too?
P: A few friends mentioned it in school once or twice, but no one seems to complain as much as me when we’re out on the field.
D: Okay, well, let’s talk about some options then. There are stronger medicines designed specifically for seasonal allergies that could be quite effective for you. We could test an antihistamine, and maybe add in a nasal spray if it's more severe.
P: Are those prescriptions? Would I need a special card or something?
D: Yes, we’ll have to write down what we decide today so that you can get them at your pharmacy. But before we do that, let’s also discuss managing things naturally—like wearing gloves when gardening and closing windows on high pollen days.
P: That makes sense! I do a lot of yard work with one of my brothers too, especially keeping flower beds clean over here.
D: Great point. How about your church activities? Do you notice anything different there?
P: Not really during services themselves. But helping in the kitchen means lots of dust and cleaning up after things, which can be rough on those days when it’s pretty bad outside.
